metadata.name: ansible
metadata.description: Ansible is a radically simple IT automation platform that makes your applications and systems easier to deploy and maintain. Automate everything from code deployment to network configuration to cloud management, in a language that approaches plain English, using SSH, with no agents to install on remote systems. https://docs.ansible.com.

issues.title: Adding custom module to find pid of the process

issues.body:
SUMMARY
This module will find the pid of the given process name either locally or in remote system, depending on the host parameter.


 ISSUE TYPE

 - New Module Pull Request


COMPONENT NAME
pids

ANSIBLE VERSION
ansible 2.8.0.dev0  last updated 2018/08/07 12:03:58 (GMT +550)
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = [u'/home/ansible/newcode/library']
  ansible python module location = /home/ansible/lib/ansible
  executable location = /home/ansible/bin/ansible
  python version = 2.7.5 (default, Jul 13 2018, 13:06:57) [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-28)]


 ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
I have used pidof module to find the process IDs(PIDs) of the given process

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Allow verifying the authenticity of the MANIFEST.json before installing and manually at any time.

The Galaxy server will be queried for signatures and a list of supplemental URLs can be provided in the requirements file:
```yaml
collections:
  - name: ns.coll
    signatures:
      - https://.../test.asc
      - file:///.../test.asc
```

Related PRs: https://github.com/pulp/pulp_ansible/pull/754, https://github.com/ansible/galaxy_ng/pull/1076

Besides ~completion~ (now feature complete) + bikeshedding, needs:
- [x] Changelog
- [x] Documentation
- [x] Tests

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Feature Pull Request

<!--- boilerplate: shippable_test_result --->

Question: @s-hertel 

Galaxy UI allows users to download the .tar.gz of the collection and will include a link to download the signature file, how it will work (in the user perspective) when they want to install off-line providing the signature path? something like

```bash
$ ansible-galaxy collection install path.to.collection.tar.gz --signature=path.to.signature 
```

?

@rochacbruno Good question. In the current iteration, install only verifies collections sourced directly from a galaxy server. This has been a requirement for `ansible-galaxy collection verify` too. But this probably needs to change (?)

`ansible-galaxy collection download` downloads the tar.gz artifacts and writes a `requirements.yml` for the user to install them, so that command could be updated to include the signatures in the requirements.yml:
```
collections:
  - name: ns-coll-1.0.0.tar.gz
    signatures:
      - file:///path/to/MANIFEST.json.asc
```
which would allow
```
ansible-galaxy collection install -r dowloaded_collections/requirements.yml
```

@s-hertel does this mean that the end-users would be able to self-sign their artifacts and then use that in offline mode? What's the trust model here? There's no CA chain-based trust here like it is in TLS. So if the expectation is that "verified" means "signed by Galaxy", isn't it possible to hijack that in offline mode?

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
This change adds new Windows Ansible module win_disk_management.

With the module you can select a disk on the server and manage it (e.g. initializing, partitioning, formatting). To select the disk and to manage it you have several options which are all described in the documentation.

Supported is:

- check mode
- diff mode
- integration tests

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_disk_management.ps1

##### ANSIBLE VERSION

```
ansible 2.4.0.0
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = [u'/root/.ansible/plugins/modules', u'/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ansible
  executable location = /usr/bin/ansible
  python version = 2.7.6 (default, Oct 26 2016, 20:30:19) [GCC 4.8.4]
```


##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Within the module you have several options to select the disk in Windows and to manage the disk, partition and volume.
```
- name: Select a defined disk and manage it as specified
  win_disk_management:
    # select_disk_by
    partition_style_select: raw
    operational_status: offline
    read_only: true
    number: 1
    # set_disk_by
    partition_style_set: mbr
    file_system: ntfs
    label: database_disk
    allocation_unit_size: 4
    large_frs: true
    short_names: true

- name: Select a defined disk and manage it as specified
  win_disk_management:
    # select_disk_by
    size: 50
    partition_style_select: mbr
    operational_status: online
    read_only: false
    # set_disk_by
    partition_style_set: gpt
    drive_letter: f
    access_path: C:\Test\
    file_system: refs
    label: application_disk
    allocation_unit_size: 64
    integrity_streams: true
```

```
No changes because the module is a new module.
```

comments_data.body:
@SamLiu79 @TimothyVandenbrande @andrewsaraceni @angstwad @ar7z1 @blakfeld @brianlloyd @chrishoffman @daBONDi @elventear @if-meaton @joshludwig @petemounce @rndmh3ro @schwartzmx @smadam813


As a maintainer of a module in the same namespace this new module has been submitted to, your vote counts for shipits. Please review this module and add `shipit` if you would like to see it merged.

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: community_shipit_notify --->

I like the idea of this of this module a lot - it would be a great addition to Ansible to have it included, but I have a few suggestions/ thoughts.

I suggest naming it 'win_disk_management' as its similar to what you can do in the Disk Management snapin.  I notice in the examples its called 'win_disk' - not sure about win_disk_setup as 'setup' at the moment is associated with the idea of gathering facts in ansible, so I'd prefer to avoid that name.

I notice in the documentation that the module parameters are all in CamelCase but ansible module parameters are usually in snake_case (lower case with words separated by _) - I think it would be best to change this for consistency (I appreciate this is not the case in powershell but within playbooks I think it would be best to be consistent).

Regarding the parameter names, I am not sure about the Find... and Set... prefixes - it makes it sound like the module isn't idempotent, and it is repetitive.

It would be a bit more work to split the parameters up so that they are in two different groups, but I think it would make it clearer.  Maybe the names below could be better but something like the following perhaps?

I also like units in the module parameter names - it makes them 'self documenting'.  So you could invoke it something like this:

```yaml
win_disk_management: 
  select_disk_by:
    size_gb: 40
    partition_style: raw
    operational_status: Online
  drive_state: 
    drive_letter: F
    allocation_unit_size_kb: 64
    file_system: NTFS
    label: ApplicationDisk
    short_names: no
    integrity_streams: no
```

@jhawkesworth The "unit in the parameter name" is not the standard way of doing it in Ansible though. I know @nitzmahone prefers this as well, but maybe this should be brought up in a Core meeting before making this a thing ;-)

I am not convinced that the selection should be part of this module. What we currently lack is proper storage device enumeration (as Windows facts). If we would have that, together with a unique reference (UUID?) to those devices, it would be easy to select a storage device and provide this unique id as input to a module that understands the desired state.

So my advice here is to focus on storage device enumeration (the Windows way) and add it to the Windows facts subsystem. Once we have that, the module becomes a lot easier (and the Windows facts can be reused in other parts of Ansible).

Now improved the output and the documentation.
@jborean93 
Have already implemented some of your change requests (preview, community, note to for working Windows version in documentation, Get-Ansibleparam and adjusted types and parameter initialization).
I will have a look to your other points now and will try to implement.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change below, including rationale and design decisions -->
This connection plugin allows Ansible to execute tasks on an EC2 instance via the  [Session Manager Plugin for the AWS CLI](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/session-manager-working-with-install-plugin.html). This is an alternative to SSH connections which eliminates the need for jumpboxes and SSH keys. Similarly, for Windows this means the control machine does not need to have username/password credentials needed for WinRM to manage the remote EC2 instance.

[Managed instances](https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2019/03/AWS_Systems_Manager_on-premises_instance_management_for_large_hybrid_environments/) provides support for on-premise instances in hybrid environments.

<!--- HINT: Include "Fixes #nnn" if you are fixing an existing issue -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest -->
- Feature Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
connection/aws_ssm

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!--- Include additional information to help people understand the change here -->
<!--- A step-by-step reproduction of the problem is helpful if there is no related issue -->

###### Prerequisites
- The remote EC2 instance must be running the [AWS Systems Manager Agent (SSM Agent)](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/ssm-agent.html)
- The remote EC2 instance must have the curl installed. On Windows, `curl` should already be present as it's an alias for [Invoke-WebRequest](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.utility/invoke-webrequest?view=powershell-6).
- The control machine must have the [AWS Session Manager Plugin](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/session-manager-working-with-install-plugin.html) installed.

###### Sample Integration Test Playbook
```
---
#
# aws_ssm test playbook
#
- name: check plugin
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: False
  tags: syntax
  vars:
    plugin_path: '../connection_plugins' # Substitute your path to aws_ssm.py here
    ignore: 'E402,E501,W503,W504,E722,E741'
    plugins:
      - 'aws_ssm'
  tasks:
  - name:  ensure the plugin exists
    command: "ls -l {{ plugin_path }}/{{ item }}.py"
    changed_when: False
    with_items: "{{ plugins }}"
  - name: install pcodestyle
    pip:
      name: pycodestyle
    become: True
  - name: check plugin style
    command: pycodestyle {{ item }}.py --ignore={{ ignore }}
    changed_when: False
    args:
      chdir: "{{ plugin_path }}/"
    with_items: "{{ plugins }}"
  - name: check docs
    command: ansible-doc --type=connection --module-path={{ plugin_path }} aws_ssm
    changed_when: False
    with_items: "{{ plugins }}"

- name: check raw command
  hosts: linux
  gather_facts: False
  tags: raw
  vars:
    pwd_stdout: '/usr/bin'
  tasks:
  - name: raw
    raw: pwd
    register: raw
    changed_when: False
  - name: check raw output
    local_action:
      module: assert
      that:
        - "raw.stdout | trim == pwd_stdout"
        - "raw.stderr == ''"
      msg: "pwd stdout '{{ raw.stdout | trim }}' != '{{ pwd_stdout }}' or stderr not blank"

- name: check escalation
  hosts: linux
  gather_facts: False
  tags: escalation
  vars:
    whoami_become_root: 'root'
    whoami_become_user: 'ec2-user'
  tasks:
  - name: whoami become
    raw: whoami
    register: whoami_root
    changed_when: False
    become: True
  - name: check whoami output
    local_action:
      module: assert
      that:
        - "whoami_root.stdout | trim == whoami_become_root"
        - "whoami_root.stderr == ''"
      msg: "whoami stdout '{{ whoami_root.stdout | trim }}' != '{{ whoami_become_root }}' or stderr not blank"

  - name: whomai become_user
    raw: whoami
    register: whoami_user
    changed_when: False
    become_user: "{{ whoami_become_user }}"
    become: True
  - name: check whoami output
    local_action:
      module: assert
      that:
        - "whoami_user.stdout | trim == whoami_become_user"
        - "whoami_user.stderr == ''"
      msg: "whoami stdout '{{ whoami_user.stdout | trim }}' != '{{ whoami_become_user }}' or stderr not blank"

- name: install python-pip
  hosts: linux
  gather_facts: False
  tags:  python-pip
  tasks:
  - name: pip
    raw: sudo yum install -y python-pip
    tags: pip

- name: check the basics - linux
  hosts: linux
  gather_facts: False
  tags: smoke
  vars:
    content: 'Some test content'
    test_filename: 'test.txt'
    remote_file: "/tmp/{{ test_filename }}"
    local_file: "/tmp/{{ inventory_hostname }}.txt"
  tasks:
  - name: ping
    ping:
    tags: ping
  - name: facts
    setup:
    tags: facts
  - name: command
    command: 'uname -a'
    changed_when: False
    tags: command
  - name: copy
    copy:
      content: "{{ content }}"
      dest: "{{ remote_file }}"
    tags: copy
  - name: fetch
    fetch:
      src: "{{ remote_file }}"
      dest: "{{ local_file }}"
      flat: yes
      validate_checksum: false
    tags: fetch
  - name: check
    assert: 
      that:
        - "item == content"
      msg: "'{{ item }}' must match '{{ content }}'"
    with_file:
      - "{{ local_file }}"
    tags: check
  - name: cleanup remote
    file:
      path: "{{ remote_file }}"
      state: absent
    tags: cleanup
  - name: cleanup local
    local_action:
      module: file
      path: "{{ local_file }}"
      state: absent
    tags: cleanup

- name: check the basics - windows
  hosts: windows
  gather_facts: False
  tags: smoke
  vars:
    content: 'Some test content'
    test_filename: 'C:\test.txt'
    remote_file: "{{ test_filename }}"
    local_file: "/tmp/{{ inventory_hostname }}.txt"
  tasks:
  - name: win_ping
    win_ping:
    tags: ping
  - name: win_command
    win_command: 'whoami'
    changed_when: False
    tags: command
  - name: win_copy
    win_copy:
      content: "{{ content }}"
      dest: "{{ remote_file }}"
    tags: copy
  - name: win_cleanup remote
    win_file:
      path: "{{ remote_file }}"
      state: absent
    tags: cleanup

- name: check timeout
  hosts: linux
  gather_facts: False
  tags:
    - never
    - timeout
  vars:
    timeout_sleep: 30 # must be greater than ansible.cfg timeout (or cli -T, --timeout) value
  tasks:
  - name: expect fatal error due to timeout
    raw: sleep {{ timeout_sleep }}
```

###### Sample Inventory
```
test:
  hosts:
    linux:
      ansible_aws_ssm_instance_id:  i-063b4d30cb2b72ad8
    windows:
      ansible_aws_ssm_instance_id: i-03b2bbacfa4117f96
      ansible_shell_type: powershell
  children:
    us-east-1:
      hosts:
        linux:
      vars:
        ansible_aws_ssm_region: us-east-1
    us-west-2:
      hosts:
        windows:
      vars:
        ansible_aws_ssm_region: us-west-2
  vars:
    ansible_aws_ssm_bucket_name: your-bucket-name
    ansible_connection: aws_ssm
```

Example ad-hoc command using sample inventory (in `hosts.yml`):
```
$ ansible test -i ./hosts.yml -m raw -a pwd
linux | CHANGED | rc=0 >>
/usr/bin

windows | CHANGED | rc=0 >>

Path
----
C:\Windows\system32


$ 
```
###### Example `managed` Instance Dockerfile
```
#
# aws-ssm-agent w/activation
#
# Get activation: aws ssm create-activation --default-instance-name "docker-ubuntu" --iam-role "your-instance-role-name" --registration-limit 10 --region us-east-1
#
# Build: docker build -t managed --build-arg AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_CODE=<YOUR_ACTIVATION_CODE> --build-arg AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_ID=<YOUR_ACTIVATION_ID> .
#
# Run: docker run --rm -it --device /dev/ttyS0 managed
#
ARG BASE=ubuntu:bionic
FROM $BASE

# Install curl
RUN apt update -q && apt install -yq \
	    curl sudo \
  && apt-get clean \
  && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/* \
  && rm -rf /tmp/*
  
ARG AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_CODE
ARG AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_ID
ARG AWS_REGION=us-east-1

RUN curl https://s3.amazonaws.com/ec2-downloads-windows/SSMAgent/latest/debian_amd64/amazon-ssm-agent.deb -o /tmp/amazon-ssm-agent.deb \
    && dpkg -i /tmp/amazon-ssm-agent.deb \
    && : "${AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_ID:?Build argument needs to be set and non-empty.}" \
    && : "${AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_CODE:?Build argument needs to be set and non-empty.}" \
    && amazon-ssm-agent -y -register -code $AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_CODE -id $AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_ID -region $AWS_REGION \
    && rm -rf /tmp/*

CMD ["amazon-ssm-agent", "start"]
```

```bash
    && dpkg -i /tmp/amazon-ssm-agent.deb \

    && : "${AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_CODE:?Build argument needs to be set and non-empty.}" \
    && amazon-ssm-agent -y -register -code $AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_CODE -id $AWS_SSM_ACTIVATION_ID -region $AWS_REGION \
    && rm -rf /tmp/*

CMD ["amazon-ssm-agent", "start"]
```

I would favour more documentation in terms of examples etc. to allow people to make use of this, as well as some built in tests, but my feeling is to get this merged before 2.8 freeze and worry about the rest after that.

We shouldn't have a connection plugin specific for Windows, it should just be the one connection plugin and the user controls the type of host with `ansible_shell_type: powershell`. This is how the ssh connection plugin now works with Windows.

issues.title: ansible-galaxy: add collection sub command

labels.name: needs_revision
labels.description: This PR fails CI tests or a maintainer has requested a review/revision of the PR.

labels.name: new_plugin
labels.description: This PR includes a new plugin.

labels.name: support:community
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible community.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: docs
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to or includes documentation.

labels.name: feature
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a feature request.

labels.name: affects_2.9
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.9

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Add the sub command `collection` to `ansible-galaxy` that can be used to manage Ansible collections. Adds the following commands for `collection`.

* `init` - Create a collection skeleton struct
* `build` - Create a collection artifact from a directory
* `publish` - Publish the collection artifact to a Galaxy server
* `install` - Installs a collection(s) from a Galaxy server or local file path.

The PR has "moved" all the existing commands for roles under `ansible-galaxy role ..` but can still be called like it is today to ensure existing workflows don't break.

Further improvements that will be looked at/add in future PRs are;

* Improve documentation around command line examples, requirements files and general collection structure
* Support specifying galaxy servers in the `~/.ansible_galaxy` config file

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Feature Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
ansible-galaxy

One other doc nit -  the top of the html page has the following text:
Perform various Role related operations.


Can you change that to say collection and role related operations?

Also would be good to have collections appear before roles if possible (to make it alphabetical) on the rendered ansible-galaxy cli page.
I take it this means 'collection init' is no longer the responsibility of molecule?
Well, https://github.com/ansible/molecule/pull/2014 was never merged

The test `ansible-test sanity --test compile --python 2.6` [[explain](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/testing/sanity/compile.html)] failed with 1 error:

Molecule can eventually do `init` based on it's cookiecutter patterns, but I think there's too much unknown right now to use it as the simple path for the first generation of collection authors. It needs a lot of overhaul to understand collections vs. roles and how+where to execute things for collections.

Aside from init, molecule is a big shell wrapper and calls other tools for all the things it does, so using `ansible-galaxy` for future things like build and publish will still be in the spirit of the architecture.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change, including rationale and design decisions -->
Allow version specifiers for pip install.
Finish #26299, #19690
<!--- If you are fixing an existing issue, please include "Fixes #nnn" in your
commit message and your description; but you should still explain what
the change does.-->

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Feature Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Name of the module, plugin, module or task -->
pip.py
##### ANSIBLE VERSION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from "ansible --version" between quotes below -->
```
ansible 2.7.0.dev0 (pip-version 0adb84aab0) last updated 2018/06/21 09:49:21 (GMT -400)
  config file = None
  configured module search path = [u'/home/zhikangzhang/.ansible/plugins/modules', u'/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /home/zhikangzhang/Desktop/ansible/lib/ansible
  executable location = /home/zhikangzhang/Desktop/ansible/bin/ansible
  python version = 2.7.14 (default, Mar 14 2018, 16:45:33) [GCC 8.0.1 20180222 (Red Hat 8.0.1-0.16)]
```


##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!--- Include additional information to help people understand the change here.
For bugs that don't have a linked bug report, a step-by-step reproduction
of the problem is helpful. -->

<!--- Paste verbatim command output below, e.g. before and after your change -->
support version specifiers, also support check mode
```
- name: install package with version specifiers
  pip:
    name: "some_package"
    version: "<100.0.0,!=1.0.0,>0.0.0"
- name: check mod
  pip:
    name: "some_package_again"
    version: "<100.0.0,!=1.0.0,>0.0.0"
  check_mode: yes
- name: also support install multi packages with one name string
  pip:
    name: "package_one>=1.11.1,<=1.12.1,package_two,package_three<=2.1.1,!=1.1.1"
- name: or install multi packages with list of name
  pip:
    name:
      - "package_one>=1.11.1,<=1.12.1"
      - "package_two"
      - "package_three<=2.1.1,!=1.1.1"
```

cc @lujeni @mattupstate @robinro
[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: notify --->
cc @abadger
Implement the param as a list rather than a string.  Make sure you then have a test that both version: "single version string" and version: [ list, of, version, specs] work

> Implement the param as a list rather than a string. Make sure you then have a test that both version: "single version string" and version: [ list, of, version, specs] work

@abadger do you mean one element of the version list corresponds to one element of the name list like this:
```
pip:
  name: 
    - package one
    - package two
  version:
    - version specifier for pk one
    - version specifier for pk two
```
or just convert string version specifier to list like ```>=1.0.1,!=1.0.0,<2.0.0``` to ```[>=1.0.1, !=1.0.0, <2.0.0]```

Associating names to versions by list index isn't good UI so we shouldn't
do it that way.

 Other packaging modules place the version strings into the names and then
parse those apart.

I'm not sure, is that the best way to do this (deprecating the separate
version parameter) or would it be better to make it an error for version to
be specified together with more than one name?

Yes

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Fixes: #46362

Adding ansible module for podman containers management

##### ISSUE TYPE
- New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
podman_container

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Adding module that manages podman_container (as it's done with docker containers)
Example:
```yaml
- name: Pull an image and start container
  podman_container:
    name: container
    image: quay.io/bitnami/wildfly
    state: started

```

> I also recall @samdoran had some podman modules around.

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/tree/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules

not maintained at all.

@webknjaz I think @EmilienM means that current podman_container module in TripleO repo is not maintained: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/podman_container.py . In addition it's pretty simple module w/o all required functionality. 
I think for TripleO would better to use ansible official feature-rich podman_container module, at least from 2.9

> @webknjaz I think @EmilienM means that current podman_container module in TripleO repo is not maintained: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/podman_container.py . In addition it's pretty simple module w/o all required functionality.
> I think for TripleO would better to use ansible official feature-rich podman_container module, at least from 2.9

yes that ^
@ssahani @EmilienM define "official". We _don't support_ community-maintained modules.

> @ssahani @EmilienM define "official". We _don't support_ community-maintained modules.

What we mean is that this PR will bring some code which hopefully will be maintained by the Ansible community but not only, also the Container team who develops Podman and the OpenStack team who consumes this module.

@EmilienM I just wanted to make clear that Ansible Core team only maintains a subset of modules marked as `"support": "core"`. Also, if somebody wants to maintain this apart from the author, they need to be added to `.github/BOTMETA.yml` to gain the power to do so.

Both `podman_image` and `podman_image_facts` are available in Ansible >= 2.8, community supported. They are the same modules linked by @EmilienM with some improvements since I first wrote them for TripleO.

@jillr wrote the `podman_container` module in TripleO. We did not include that with Ansible 2.8 since it was not something on our roadmap (TBH, the other Podman modules weren't either. I just did those in my free time, wearing my "community" hat :smile:).
To ease the burden of maintenance, even without the help of the community, I'd suggest to add some unit tests on the module.
I'd even recommend integration tests since they are usually more useful.
Of course, added integration tests as well @webknjaz @gabrielecerami

@samdoran @TomasTomecek  @webknjaz meanwhile when CI is fixed, are there any issues or things I need to fix or improve?
@webknjaz thanks! The plans for a weekend are cleared up now :smile:
@webknjaz thanks! I'm starting to work on second iteration, so I'd happy to get reviews and fix what is left to fix, including docstrings.

I made [a comment](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/39656#pullrequestreview-119193759) about the name, we usually name modules after the product only, not the vendor. So my suggestion was to use **3par_cpg** instead. The author does not want the module to start with a number.

As a follow-up, we named the HP iLO modules hpilo, but I guess we now have to call it [hpeilo](https://www.hpe.com/be/en/servers/integrated-lights-out-ilo.html) ? ;-)

So IMO it's better not to add vendor names in module names.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Added a new dynamic inventory plugin to integrate Ansible with Docker Machine, just like the existing Docker Swarm dynamic inventory plugin in Ansible 2.8.

##### ISSUE TYPE
- New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
docker_machine.py

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
See https://github.com/ximon18/ansible-docker-machine-inventory-plugin for more information.

The intent of this PR is to begin the process of proposing the module for inclusion in Ansible core. However, there are no unit or integration tests yet. The docker_swarm inventory plugin has integration 
 tests but has some concerning note in its 'aliases' file about disabling docker due to test instability and also I wouldn't know at this point how to get Docker Machine installed on the integration test platform. I did not find any unit tests for the existing docker_swarm inventory plugin to use as a basis for my own module.

Tested with Ansible 2.7.10, Docker Machine 0.16.0, Python 3.6.7 on Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS.

Thanks,

Ximon

> Please note that Feature Freeze for Ansible 2.8 is coming up very soon (Thursday, April 11), so the chances for this PR making it into Ansible 2.8 aren't very high. I'll try to give you more feedback tomorrow (gotta go sleeping now), but be warned that I don't have any experience with docker machine.

Thx, v appreciated.

FYI [this](https://github.com/NLnetLabs/gantry/blob/819d45cdcb3939169a9e9b61915e2707f0ade9a0/cli#L74) is where I am using Docker Machine and [this](https://github.com/NLnetLabs/gantry/blob/819d45cdcb3939169a9e9b61915e2707f0ade9a0/cli#L99) is where I invoke Ansible with my Docker Machine dynamic inventory plugin, and [this](https://github.com/NLnetLabs/gantry/blob/master/playbooks/vr-sros:16.0.R6.yml) is a playbook that references the created variables. Perhaps it helps to see it used.
 
> PS: there are more places where you can improve formatting using the syntax from the link. I just didn't want to mark everything now ;)

I took a look at the Docker Swarm inventory plugin docs and added a few more uses of the link syntax.

It's perhaps a bit of a strange test case but to avoid the need for a remote machine to test against one could in theory enable ssh server in a docker container, publish the ssh port, then tell Docker machine to connect to it using the `--generic` driver. This also makes me wonder if all driver support tags and if not the code may not be defensive against missing tags, I need to check. Perhaps I can setup such a test.

@DBendit @WojciechowskiPiotr @akshay196 @danihodovic @dariko @felixfontein @jwitko @kassiansun @tbouvet Did anyone of you ever used docker-machine? If yes, please take a look at this PR, your input would really be appreciated :) (and if you haven't, also feel free, of course ;) )

> The docker_swarm inventory plugin has integration tests but has some concerning note in its 'aliases' file about disabling docker due to test instability

This shouldn't matter for docker-machine; the main problem with docker swarm is that putting the daemon into swarm mode and out of swarm mode, and changing swarm parameters, is making the daemon unstable if you do it too often in a row. Especially the tests for docker_swarm (module, not inventory plugin) have to do it a lot (otherwise they can't test many of the features), so we had a lot of problems with this in the past and had to take some aggressive measures to "fix" this - including killing the docker daemon at the end of the tests (shutting it down regularly sometimes timeouted after 45 minutes) and bringing it up again. Since most of the tests actually don't run in VMs, but in docker containers themselves, this would have wrecked the whole test system, whence the docker swarm tests now only run in the proper VMs (which at the moment is RHEL7 and RHEL8 on the CI nodes).

For docker machine, that shouldn't be such a problem. It might not work well with a docker container, since running docker inside docker is not really working. But it might be possible in the VMs. I don't know the testing system well enough to be able to say anything about this, though.

You should definitely still add some integration tests, but marked as `unsupported` (see https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/dev_guide/testing/sanity/integration-aliases.html). You can leave all setup code (i.e. installing ansible-machine) away for now, just make sure that the resulting tests work if ansible-machine is already installed (and whatever else you need to make basic tests).

When that's done, we should talk to the test people about what is needed to actually make tests work in CI. But that's not that urgent, as long as there are some basic tests which can at least be started manually.
Thanks for taking the time to provide excellent feedback. I will incorporate your suggestions as soon as I can.

I agree. There is JSON export (`docker-machine inspect`) but it doesn't for
some reason include the correct right DOCKER_HOST tcp:// output...

Looks like a great module, thanks a lot!

Your module is called "dellemc_install_firmware", that indicates an action, not a state. Ansible typically expresses a state. I would expects a module name like dellemc_firware or so.
Moreover: module names usually refer to things (objects) they manage, while the state is expressed via the state argument.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY

This PR adds the snap module to manage snaps packages (see [snapcraft.io](https://snapcraft.io)).

Features:

- install snap
- install snap with [classic confinement](https://docs.snapcraft.io/reference/confinement)
- install snap from a specific [channel](https://docs.snapcraft.io/t/channels/551)
- remove snap

It is based on the PR https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/40852 and the work made by @vcarceler. (Thanks a bunch!)
His branch runs against a number of issues against the CI and he has not made any update in 3 months, so I'm finishing the work. In the end, I did a bit of refactoring 😄 

This fixes issue https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/39155.

* All sanity tests are now successful (and the module actually works! 🎉)
* I improved the module documentation
* I removed a lot of code and comments that were just a copy/paste from the [ansible doc's sample module](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/dev_guide/developing_modules_general.html#new*module*development). Most of it was unneeded. Some just broked the code.
* I refactored the code:
  * It's easier to read and understand
  * It's shorter
  * Functions make more sense
  * Some bugs have been fixed, like the output on `exit_json` and `fail_json`

I would like to implement more features like `snap refresh`, but sadly I don't think this is feasible in a clean way for now, considering how the cli works.

Any feedback is welcome! I'm new to this.

##### ISSUE TYPE

 - New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME

```
snap
```

More specifically:

```
packaging/os/snap
```

##### ANSIBLE VERSION

```sh
$ ansible --version
ansible 2.7.0.a1.post0 (snapcraft fc4e1c9b46) last updated 2018/08/30 21:27:31 (GMT +200)
  config file = None
  configured module search path = ['/Users/stanislas/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /Users/stanislas/lab/ansible/lib/ansible
  executable location = /Users/stanislas/lab/ansible/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.7.0 (default, Jul  7 2018, 00:33:58) [Clang 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.2)]
```

Wow! Impressive work. Let me do some tests

- When a snap is not installed, `present` won't do anything
- When a snap is installed, `absent` won't do anything
- When a snap is not installed, `absent` will try to remove it (err)
- When a snap is installed, `present` will try to install it (err)
I think the issues comes from `get_snap_for_action`, more specifically the `if predicate(s)` condition.

##### SUMMARY
New module to handle Docker Swarm node operations. It must be executed on Swarm `manager` node and allows changing the node availability, role, and labels (fixes #49547). Part of the commit is also a shared library for all common methods for other Swarm modules.

##### ISSUE TYPE
- New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
docker_node

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
This PR is a copy of #50428, required due to the wrong branch in original PR. The open discussion in old PR is on module name and where put some inspect features, either in `docker_node` or `docker_node_facts` (#50571). The upcoming `docker_swarm_facts` will use the shared code from this PR. 
This module is equivalent of `docker node` CLI command allowing now changing the node availability and role as well as applying or removing the labels from the node. It must be executed on Swarm manager node otherwise exception is raised. 
When RP is merged into `ansible/devel` then we can update `docker_swarm` module so it uses the shared methods from `module_utils/docker_swarm` instead of own local wherever it is possible.

ready_for_review

Would be nice to get this PR reviewed and hopefully merged in parallel to #50571 as those are not in conflict to each other

I think it makes more sense to first get #50571 merged, and then modify `docker_node_facts` to use the new module_utils as well (in this PR) -- as well as discuss whether the `list` mode should be moved to `docker_node_facts` (I'm kind of in favor of this).

Anyway, to get something merged, some more reviews are needed. Anyone? :)
Now that #50571 has been merged, can you rebase this PR against `devel` and make `docker_node_facts` use the new module_utils as well?

The change in `docker_node_facts` is purely cosmetic, already committed in my repo, will be part of next push to this PR.

As @tbouvet agreed with me in #50428, we will use the `docker_node` as the module name. That would put changing the name of `docker_service` into `docker_compose` in more flavor so we can later rename `docker_swarm_service` into `docker_service`. It will take six releases, but I think it is good for modules convention sanity in `cloud/docker`. 

As for the `list` as I said before in #50428 only the `docker_image_facts` does not require `name` parameter, and it accepts a list of strings. Other modules require a single string as `name`. The CLI commands aways allows a list of objects to inspect (empty list not allowed) and provides the `ls` action to just list objects with basic information. I like the approach where the `_facts` module is like an `inspect` and `non-_facts` have an implementation of `ls` command.

I think the options to consider are:

1. Leave `docker_node_facts` as it is, so it returns information on a single node, adjusts the `docker_image_facts` to this approach, create the `ls` command implementation in an operational module, it may cover the filters as well
- Pros: Easy `docker_*_facts` modules in code, the single way you can use them in playbooks
- Cons: Playbook developer need to know the name of the object to inspect every time, so there should be some kind of implementation of CLI command `docker [network,image,container,etc] ls` in each module to give a list of objects
- Consistency with CLI - partial

2. Let parameter `name` optional in all `docker_*_facts` modules and accept the list as a parameter, if `name` not provided then return information about all objects.
- Pros: Easy way to get information on every object, specific objects or a single object, shouldn't be hard to implement. May include filters too.
- Cons: If called without a `name` parameter it returns lots of information, and later the playbook code may not be so clear due to big multi-levels structures user have to parse. If it covers the filters as well, it will increase the complexity of the facts modules
- Consistency with CLI - partial

3. Let parameter `name` optional in all `docker_*_facts` modules and accept the list as a parameter, if `name` not provided then return information about all objects but also add the `ls` command output to the operation modules.
- Pros: Easy way to get information on every object, specific objects or a single object, shouldn't be hard to implement. The `_facts` will not allow additional filtering, this feature will be implemented as part of the `non-_facts` module.
- Cons: If called without a `name` parameter it returns lots of information and later the playbook code may not be so clear due to big multi-levels structures user have to parse. If it covers the filters as well, it will increase the complexity of the facts modules
- Consistency with CLI - full

4. Let parameter `name` required as list of `strings` and implement the `ls` method in each non-facts module. This way `facts` modules will return the full information on at least single object, while `ls` command implementation returns limited information and can cover filters
- Pros: Playbook developer will call the `facts` module to inspect known objects, because it will be a list it will be possible to get information in one task, the `ls` command implementation in each module may return the structure identical to the CLI, so limited in number of information, it can also cover the filters
- Cons: Need a `ls` command implementation in each module
- Consistency with CLI - full

One more thing worth noticing is the difference between Swarm and non-Swarm hosts. The non-Swarm modules (`image`, `container`, `volume`, `network`) you need to run on every host in inventory while swarm modules (with some exceptions of node operations not proposed yet in this PR) have to be run on hosts acting as Swarm Managers. This role is dynamic by its nature and promoting/demoting nodes shouldn't be unusual operation to keep a quorum in the cluster. Also, each manager will return same information about the cluster and its components (node, config, secret, other swarm modules) so it will be a waste of time and resources to run facts module on each node from inventory every time.

With the approach in point 4) the playbook developer may fetch the nodes lists and roles from `docker_node` using `state: list` to get a simple structure with just 6 or 7 attributes as in `docker node ls` command output, he may use additional filters as well. It is easy to use the list if playbook runs on localhost and uses the API. With SSH and hosts in inventory dynamic states in Swarm are not so easy to handle when you try to minimize number of tasks in playbook, time to run it and resources it will require. 

To sum this up - I like the consistency between the modules and I like the idea that modules are working in similar way as CLI because most people will first know the CLI then will try automate the tasks. My preference is option **4** in this case, but I am happy to go with approach most of the docker modules maintainers here will recommend as preferred.

There are a few things to consider:
1. Normal modules should do something (except for check mode), and `_facts` modules should query stuff without modifying. Having data querying functionality in normal modules is discouraged. I'm definitely against adding a `list`/`ls` method to any non-`_facts` module. If there is `list`/`ls` support, it should be handled by the `_facts` module (or by a new module).
2. Ansible should not mirror exactly what can be done via CLI or API, but what is useful. Is there a concrete need for getting a list of containers, images, ...? I can see that it makes sense for Swarm nodes, but I doubt it for other objects.

Also, for offering lists in a `_facts` module, I would prefer having a choices option `results` with default value `single`, and alternative choice `list` (names open for bikeshedding as usual ;) ). For `single`, `name` would be required; for `list`, it would not be (and will be ignored).

1. This is a good argument against my approach and I have no problem in going this way
2. It is not a necessity to mirror but if it's not against the general usage then why it shouldn't? 

You mean a list in input or output? As input I think best would be as it is in `docker_image_facts` plus if `name` is missing then it returns facts about all objects.

About 2: because it increases complexity, both for the module's code and for the module's documentation. If there's a good enough usecase, I don't mind having it, but having it just because we can doesn't seem like a good idea for me.

I meant lists as output. I don't think there's a use for having lists as input; one can use task-level loops if one really has one. (At least, I can't think of a good use for having lists as input. And I wouldn't mind getting rid of the lists input for `docker_image_facts`; unfortunately it has been there already for a longer time...)

The input list may be useful if you want to check against your inventory, by example the inventory group of all supposed workers and provide it to one of managers to get info about the workers.

Also, it will be useful to allow filters `label`, `membership` and `role` as per API documentation:

```
Available filters:

id=<node id>
label=<engine label>
membership=(accepted|pending)`
name=<node name>
role=(manager|worker)`
```
Do you mean `docker_container_facts` or `docker_node_facts`? And why not use Ansible's task-level loop facility for such a use-case?

In `docker_node_facts`. Both input list and filters are meant to limit the number of information you want later to process in the playbook. Of course, there is nothing wrong in getting information on all registered nodes, then in the next tasks loop through the results, make conditionals etc but that increases the complexity of playbook and usually makes it harder to read. 

If you look at other groups in the `cloud` most `_facts` modules allows limiting the scope by `filters`, or `labels`, sometimes more vendor-specific attribute. Especially the AWS, Azure, GCP or OpenStack modules

cc @wojciechowskipiotr
[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: notify --->

I didn't say that `docker_node_facts` cannot have a list output; for me, that's the only `docker_*_facts` module where I see that it is useful to have that functionality.

For me, the `*_facts` modules query information about a specific object: `docker_container_facts` about a docker container, `docker_volume_facts` about a docker volume, etc. So for me, `docker_node_facts` gets facts about a specific node. That's why I would suggest to add two modes to it: one for querying a specific node (with `exists` information being returned, and where an input list makes no sense), and one for listing nodes (where you can filter and whatever to get a list of nodes in the end). Since the functionality is so disjoint, how about having it in two different modules? The list functionality could also be a part of `docker_swarm_facts`, since listing nodes is something you can get from a swarm (and not from a node).

(I checked some random openstack modules and didn't saw any list input. Also, the GCP modules are special since they are auto-generated from the API. In the AWS modules I saw indeed some with list input. It really depends on what you want to do with the queried information. Whether you are interested in one specific object, or whether you want to list and filter.)

> The list functionality could also be a part of docker_swarm_facts, since listing nodes is something you can get from a swarm (and not from a node).

I agree with @felixfontein . List of nodes is a functionality of swarm not a functionality of a node (_see my comment in the review_).
So It would be better to put `list` function in `docker_swarm_facts`.

Some thoughts about `docker_node` now.

`state: update` - update the node parameters (role, availability, labels defined as additional parameters), must be run on swarm manager. The parameters that are not specified in task remains unchanged. The promotion and demotion between `manager` and `worker` roles on CLI can be done via CLI commands `docker node promote` and `docker node demote` but I am happy to leave all in `state: update` for clarity.
And at this moment it will be the only state, might be defined as default giving the possibility to have more states in future depending on new features in docker itself. It also leaves joining and leaving as well as removing `down` nodes as operations in `docker_swarm` module.

The `docker_swarm_facts` have to include swarm inspection (the `state: inspect` in current `docker_swarm`), swarm node lists (`docker node ls`) with filters and swarm node tasks lists `docker node ps`) with filters.

Any thoughts?

The test `ansible-test sanity --test validate-modules` [[explain](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/testing/sanity/validate-modules.html)] failed with 1 error:
```
lib/ansible/modules/cloud/docker/docker_node.py:0:0: E326 Value for "choices" from the argument_spec (['present', 'leave']) for "state" does not match the documentation (['list', 'update'])
```
<!-- job_id: 5c37c4faf61c8e07005fcb63 -->
<!-- job_id: 5c37c5003e89d50800c30c3e -->
<!-- job_id: /testresults/ansible-test-sanity-validate-modules.json -->

CC @DBendit @WojciechowskiPiotr @akshay196 @danihodovic @dariko @jwitko @kassiansun @tbouvet @hannseman, which are also interested in docker and/or docker swarm.

One general thought about this plugin - it should return discovered hosts in 4 groups:

- all - for all discovered nodes
- managers - swarm managers
- workers - swarm workers
- leader - single entry of swarm leader 

Many tasks I can think of should be performed on a leader node.
@WojciechowskiPiotr : good catch! Will do....

I am gonna give it some more test as I am not much familiar with those plugins, I used external scripts for dynamic inventory so far. At this moment I am not sure if our recommendations, including mine, make plugin consistent, but I like the idea! Yesterday I was trying to use `add_host` module to generate dynamic inventory based on an output of swarm modules but it didn't work as expected.

> @WojciechowskiPiotr: I'm adding `ansible_host` as metadata, so we can actually use the node-ids and still connect (example below is a test swarm using docker-in-docker ;) ):

This looks perfect! Just to confirm - you can still use the group entries, the ID identifiers, as a list to provide it as a parameter to `loop` or to `name:` in `docker_node_facts`?

One more feature idea - allow providing more than one `name` entry in the configuration file. Or secondary entry for the second host? The idea is to have the second manager node there in case the first one did not respond. If first respond you don't query the second one.
Can you give an example how to act using `loop:` or `name:` ?

> [102c105](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/102c105e2893099f5c0da8dac16b0491254aa16e) will make all data available in `docker_swarm_node_attributes`, so one can act on all available info like:

I don't think it should be there. It is an inventory plugin. For reading the details there are `_facts` modules, the plugin should just provide the information about swarm members.
Good catch, reverted.

Actually that's a good question. I have no experience with inventory plugins, but if we already have the `inspect` results for each node, it might make sense to include them (i.e. re-add 102c105e2893099f5c0da8dac16b0491254aa16e). I'll ask on IRC.

Feedback from #ansible-devel: return the information, or at least provide a config toggle whether this information should be provided or not (in that case, I'd use the default `yes`). (Only if there'd be need to do another API call to retrieve this information, and it's not needed elsewhere, then it definitely shouldn't be returned by default, but only if another option is added for it with default `no`).

The test `ansible-test sanity --test pylint` [[explain](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/testing/sanity/pylint.html)] failed with 2 errors:


> Feedback from #ansible-devel: return the information, or at least provide a config toggle whether this information should be provided or not (in that case, I'd use the default `yes`). (Only if there'd be need to do another API call to retrieve this information, and it's not needed elsewhere, then it definitely shouldn't be returned by default, but only if another option is added for it with default `no`).

I can't think of usage as part of an inventory except for a case where you want to loop ever particular attribute, by example the CPU platform, but you can do this reading the facts module. It may be used to group the inventory objects. If we re-add it then it should be as an option.

> Can you give an example how to act using `loop:` or `name:` ?

Using the `hostvars` elements

Why use the facts module, when you already got all the facts? Throwing away information which you have to get again is wasteful.

And having for example the node state could be useful (drained, paused, ...), if you want to preform certain tasks (like update software, reboot, ...) depending on this.

> Why use the facts module, when you already got all the facts? Throwing away information which you have to get again is wasteful.
> 
> And having for example the node state could be useful (drained, paused, ...), if you want to preform certain tasks (like update software, reboot, ...) depending on this.

I think in most cases people would use the facts modules anyway because the playbooks are meant to be reusable and independent from inventory plugins. I don't mind the information in plugin just would make it optional.

issues.body:
<!---
Verify first that your issue/request is not already reported on GitHub.
Also test if the latest release, and master branch are affected too.
-->

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Name of the module/plugin/task/feature -->
ansible-playbook

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from “ansible --version” between quotes below -->
```
ansible 2.3.1.0
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
  python version = 2.7.5 (default, Aug  2 2016, 04:20:16) [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-4)]
```

##### CONFIGURATION
<!---
[defaults]
host_key_checking = False
timeout = 20
retry_files_save_path = /home/ansible/retry/
# Do not put more jobs here, or ssh will fail

<!---
RHEL 7.3
-->

##### SUMMARY
<!--- Explain the problem briefly -->

When running ansible playbook for all servers (1964 servers) it hangs somewhere in middle of execution. I used -vvvvvvvvvv to trace the problem, but it doesn't print ANYTHING. The previous host finishes and the message about finish is last thing I see in console, then there is NOTHING. It just hangs. It doesn't even print the FQDN or name of server that is next in queue, it doesn't say what is is waiting for. Just nothing.

In ps I see 2 processes: Running strace shows:

parent:
Process 22170 attached
select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 599})   = 0 (Timeout)

wait4(28917, 0x7ffd44d0bf64, WNOHANG, NULL) = 0
select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 1000})  = 0 (Timeout)
wait4(28917, 0x7ffd44d0bf34, WNOHANG, NULL) = 0
wait4(28917, 0x7ffd44d0bf64, WNOHANG, NULL) = 0

...
repeats forever

child:
Process 28917 attached
epoll_wait(40, 


##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!---
For bugs, show exactly how to reproduce the problem, using a minimal test-case.
For new features, show how the feature would be used.
-->

<!--- Paste example playbooks or commands between quotes below -->
```yaml
# This playbook is used to test if server works or not

---
- hosts: run-tools.homecredit.net all:!ignored
  tasks:
  - command: echo works
```

Looks like a bug to me, it should at least tell me what it's trying to do that causes the hang

comments_data.body:
You can enable debug mode to get more information than `-v*` gives you. To do this just export `ANSIBLE_DEBUG=1` to enable it.

We would probably need some more info to try and help you with this which hopefully the debug logs will provide. That many hosts does seem like a lot to connect concurrently, are you running in parallel or in blocks of hosts?

needs_info

Hmm, what are you setting forks to?  Hitting lots of hosts at once might be taking up a lot of resources - worth checking /var/log/messages too.

You might like to try wait_for_connection as a way of testing that all your hosts are available. Its nice as its aware of the connection type so it works even if you have mixed inventory of say windows and linux hosts.

Hi, it's connecting max to 10 hosts at same time, this is config:

```
[defaults]
host_key_checking = False
timeout = 20
retry_files_save_path = /home/ansible/retry/
# Do not put more jobs here, or ssh will fail
# Anything more than 10 kills this poor server
forks = 10
remote_user = root
log_path=/var/log/ansible.log

[ssh_connection]
retries=3
pipelining=True
```

I managed to find a "block of hosts" that contain the one which is probably causing this hang, so I am now removing more and more hosts from that temporary file with hope to identify the one that causes this.

My rough guess is that it maybe hangs on DNS query? It's possible that one of these hosts doesn't exist and misconfigured DNS server make the query take forever? I have no idea, but I am fairly sure that no detailed information is available even in debug log, I will try to provide that one soonish. I see some debug lines, then I see green ok: [hostname] and then nothing forever, not a single debug or verbose line, it just hangs.

```
 12502 1506511086.64166: Loading CallbackModule 'default' from /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ansible/plugins/callback/default.py (found_in_cache=False, class_only=True)
```

Here it hangs forever. I replaced domain of this company with "domain.tld", the actual domain name is different.

This is still bug in Ansible at least in a sense that Ansible should produce some verbose ERROR message that will let user know which host is causing the hang-up so that the host can be removed from inventory file with no need for complex investigation of what went wrong.

Also running a large inventory (2400+), seeing similar errors, and going through the same lengthy troubleshooting in hopes of finding log verbosity that points me in a better direction.
```
ansible 2.4.1.0
python version = 2.7.5 (default, May  3 2017, 07:55:04) [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-14)]
```

Seeing it get to the end of a playbook and not getting the futex and closing calls. From the strace of a job that show the problem : 
```
21:39:26 stat("/var/lib/awx/projects/<job>/host_vars", 0x7ffd4ce0dfd0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
21:39:26 stat("/var/lib/awx/.cache/facts/<host>", 0x7ffd4ce0dae0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
21:39:26 stat("/var/lib/awx/.cache/facts/<host>", 0x7ffd4ce0dcf0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
21:39:26 select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 1000}) = 0 (Timeout)
21:39:26 select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, {0, 1000}) = 0 (Timeout)
... infinite Timeout
```

From a successful job : 
```
21:39:39 stat("/var/lib/awx/projects/<job>/host_vars", 0x7ffd4ce0dfd0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
21:39:39 stat("/var/lib/awx/.cache/facts/<host>", 0x7ffd4ce0dae0) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)

21:39:39 close(7)                       = 0
... continues to close and wrap up
```
@benapetr / @jmighion how did you guys solve the underlying problem? Trying to figure out a workaround when issues like this arise

There are multiple reasons why this can happen. I never said I found a solution. You can in theory run the playbook by hand in a loop on each host separately to figure out which one is causing problems, and then you need to investigate this host.

Good example of problem that can cause this is disconnected NFS mount, which would hang even "df" command.
Sorry, don't remember finding a solution. I think ours was hanging on a device we were trying to connect to, but honestly cant say. We're not hitting the problem anymore though.

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/30411#issuecomment-360766621
> Good example of problem that can cause this is disconnected NFS mount, which would hang even > "df" command.

That was exactly my problem. No ansible.cfg parameter(neither timeout fact_caching_timeout) did helped me to interrupt the process. Thank you so much!
IMO this schould result in a error/timeout on the control machine.

I had a similar issue, I set `pipelining` from `True` to `False`, run the playbook (successfully after this change) and then set back to `True` whereafter subsequent playbook runs also worked correctly.

Edit: @benapetr: Thanks! This was actually the underlying issue. A folder is mounted over SSHFS through a reverse SSH tunnel (for pushing from ansible control machine). After manually connecting over SSH to target machine and unmounting `umount -l ...` the problem went away.

Looks like I have a similar problem with ansible and an nfs mount on the target. lsof, df, ansible.. all hanging.
Setting the pipelining to false in the ansible.cfg did not help.

@jeroenflvr: In my case the sshfs mount hangs (also when invoking the mount command manually). I switched to CIFS/samba mount over the SSH reverse tunnel and now it works without hanging. This seems to be partly fuse- but not ansible-related.

it doesn't matter if hang on target host is caused by fuse, nfs or anything, it's still Ansible bug in the way that 1 target host should not be able to lock up whole play for all other hosts.

There must be some timeout or internal watchdog implemented that would kill playbook for misbehaving and broken machines. 1 broken machine out of 5000 shouldn't break Ansible for all 5000 machines.

@benapetr yes, this has to be tackled some day. not as a bug, but as a design issue, such hangs are the big plague and no single "fix" will resolve them for real. I occasionally used it since 2011, and IMO it'll always be like this until finally someone accepts something has to be done on a higher level.

Same issue for me.
I have six MacOS hosts and i run:
`ansible-playbook tcmacagents.yml -f 6`
It hangs on first step "Gathering Facts". Always on the same host(tcmacagent5):

How i can fix it? What wrong with my tcmacagent5?
```
# ansible --version
ansible 2.5.0
```

If it is a mount and it is not usable(touch a file or something) remount it. In my special situation i always reverted a vm to a snapshot for testing purposes and the NFS handle doesnt match within this vm - so it is in stale state

We have also been experiencing Ansible hanging without any error message, when running playbooks against  23 hosts, with `forks=25`. We use Ansible 2.2.3.0, but have the same problem with Ansible 2.5.3. We run our playbooks from macOS 10.12.6, using Python 2.7.15. With `forks=5`I don't see the problem. We also don't see the problem when using `transport=paramiko` (and `forks=25`).
We have the same issue. Playbooks randomly hangs during playback with no error messages. Once pressing ctrl + c the playbook continues.

comments_data.body: Migrated from https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-extras/pull/2069

@mscherer I believe you looked at the original review https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-extras/pull/2069

Would you please be able to look at this now it's been ported to the new repo, thanks
shipit

@AugustusKling @rosmo @mcv21 @DavidWittman @mulby @srvg @abulimov @dsummersl @EvanK @goozbach @nibalizer @groks @LinusU @risaacson @dagwieers @dougluce @tmshn @jasperla @saito-hideki @jhoekx @natefoo @mscherer @matze @maxamillion @davixx @ovcharenko @pyykkis @pmarkham @stygstra @dankeder


As a maintainer of a module in the same namespace this new module has been submitted to, your vote counts for shipits. Please review this module and add `shipit` if you would like to see it merged.

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: community_shipit_notify --->

I don't know if it's required, but some modules have `ANSIBLE_METADATA`.
How about adding this?

E.g.;
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/system/timezone.py#L31-L33
I'll look into adding the `ANSIBLE_METADATA`, thanks.
shipit

Is the module name `portenforce` is good? ......I'm thinking 🤔 
It sounds okay once I know what this module will do, but...it might be difficult to know by name at a glance.

I don't have good alternatives, but how about something like `non_listening_port`?

Apart from the name, I don't think killing processes that listen on ports is a good pattern. I understand you want to ensure that only services you have configured are running, but killing them, why ?

Why would there be processes running that you have no control over listening on ports ? To listen on ports < 1024 you need root privileges. So do you have trust-issues with other root-users ? Or is this a poor-man's attempt to fight the people that owned your server ?

Problem is that these processes can be restarted and the problem resurfaces. So I don't think this is a good practice in whatever scenario you are in because it gives a false sense of security and doesn't give real control.

I would reconsider offering this module altogether.
Probably reporting *what* runs on ports what you didn't allow is more interesting approach.

As mentioned in the original description the idea is this contributes a small part of a more offensive approach to system security. I wouldn't describe it as trying to mitigate against a rouge user or malware on its own - it's just a small layer that attempts to enforce system security state. 

So imagine an organisation who determines that System X is expected to have TCP 22, 80, and 443 listening - if a `portenforce` (yeah not the best name) role checks and enforces this on a regular basis, say via some sort of ansible pull, that contributes actively to the security profile of the system.

Reporting on violations is probably more interesting and practical, agreed - it supports check mode for this reason.

@ndavison You can rename it to `listen_port_audit` or similar to reflect what's doing. As for killing processes, @dagwieers mentioned already what this doesn't help to make system secure: the same process could be re-spawning the same moment you killed it. So why to do so?

You can feed whatever your module found to [ufw](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/system/ufw.py) module in playbook, but having default firewall policy to block all unwanted traffic is preferred over this :)
I'm -1 for the same reasons as @gundalow. I think that this should be handled elsewhere...
@gundalow @LinusU we have few modules in Ansible what just collect facts:  ec2_facts, setup; just to name a few. This one can be one of them if committer will update it.

@ovcharenko @gundalow @LinusU @dagwieers Happy to change this to a fact collecting module only and remove the pid killing, but first I'll try and find out if some other module doesn't already offer this (seeing as determining listening ports can be solved a couple of ways, not just parsing netstat). If not, `listen_ports` or `listen_ports_facts` would sound like a more appropriate name?

Would this be better done as updating this pull request or starting a new one?
@ndavison please update pull request **SUMMARY** and **COMPONENT NAME** to reflect recent module changes

@ndavison In my opinion, your module makes more sense as part of a facts-plugin. Currently the gather_facts stage (setup module) is pretty monolithic. But there is a wish to make it more modular so people can add their own facts-plugins (and switch them on/off at will) for either customer-specific stuff, or very specific needs. And yours is one of these.

@gundalow Do we have a ~roadmap~timeline of when this kind of functionality is discussed/implemented, because I think it would simplify Ansible's design and gives facts modules a proper place in the ecosystem.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY

This satisfies the feature request in #60120 

There currently exists the `aws_acm_facts` module. (Which appears to have been renamed to `aws_acm_info` in the devel branch.) This fetches data about certificates in Amazon's certificate manager (ACM).

This PR adds a new module, `aws_acm`, which is used to create, modify and delete ACM resources. (Only self-provided certificates for now, not the Amazon-managed ones.)

As part of this I have:

* factored out the bulk of `aws_acm_info` into a `module_util`, so it can be used by both `aws_acm` and `aws_acm_info`.
* converted `aws_acm_info` to an AWS Ansible module. Previously it was a generic Ansible module.
* Added integration tests for `aws_acm_info` and `aws_acm`. (It makes sense to test them together. You can't test cert creation unless you can get cert info. And you can't test getting cert info unless you create a cert.)
* added more filtering options for `aws_acm_info`

##### ISSUE TYPE

- New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME

aws_acm
aws_acm_info

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

I have written a unit test for `aws_acm`. When I manually run it with `ansible-test units --docker --python 2.7` it works. Can someone please double check that the CICD will invoke this test? (I just added the file. I don't know whether I need to point something towards it.)

```
(<ansible.plugins.callback.default.CallbackModule object at 0x7f369c13d510>):
'NoneType' object has no attribute 'strip'
```

What does that mean? This task succeeds when run as a normal playbook. So I have the right syntax.
This task uses `certificate_complete_chain`. Was a bug introduced to `certificate_complete_chain` in the devel branch? When I run the integration test for `certificate_complete_chain`, every meaningful task in the playbook is skipped by Ansible.

I am also not certain that I have added all required permissions to `hacking/aws_config/testing_policies/security-policy.json`

(Note that @mlda065 and @matt-telstra are the same person. I'm switching account for the pull request because this is a contribution on behalf of my employer.)
