issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change, including rationale and design decisions -->
 Manages Out-Of-Band controllers using Redfish APIs:
  - Builds Redfish URIs locally and sends them to remote OOB controllers to get information back.
  - Information retrieved is placed in a location specified by the user.

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Name of the module, plugin, module or task -->
redfish_facts

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from "ansible --version" between quotes below -->
```
ansible 2.7.0.dev0 (redfish_facts 94ab116010) last updated 2018/06/18 09:47:48 (GMT -500)
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = [u'/root/.ansible/plugins/modules', u'/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /share1/git/ansible/lib/ansible
  executable location = /share1/git/ansible/bin/ansible
  python version = 2.7.5 (default, Feb 20 2018, 09:19:12) [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-28)]
```

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!--- Include additional information to help people understand the change here.
For bugs that don't have a linked bug report, a step-by-step reproduction
of the problem is helpful. -->
The Distributed Management Task Force (who specifies the Redfish spec) will extend functionality and maintain this community module.

comments_data.body: Follow up to https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/41297, where original module was broken up into 3 smaller modules for a better user experience. This PR is for first module (redfish_facts), according to the [grouped modules documentation](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/developing_modules_in_groups.html).
@willthames @juliakreger Do you mind updating your review (originally on #41297) now that this is being split into several modules?

@samdoran, I implemented the approach you suggested. As more Redfish APIs become available the list of commands within each category can also be expanded. I implemented the capability to not add a command (uses default), pass more than one command within the same category, and pass the "all" command, which will invoke all commands within a category.

I also rearranged some of the categories to better mirror the categories provided by the Redfish API spec.

I created a separate branch [redfish_facts_proposed](https://github.com/jose-delarosa/ansible/tree/redfish_facts_proposed) with these changes. If they are acceptable I can merge updates back into the original redfish_facts branch.

Let me know if this is close to what you were thinking. I appreciate your feedback.

[redfish_facts.py](https://github.com/jose-delarosa/ansible/blob/redfish_facts_proposed/lib/ansible/modules/remote_management/redfish/redfish_facts.py)
@jose-delarosa I like the approach in `redfish_facts_proposed`. Go ahead and merge that into this branch and we can give it a final review. Thanks!
Thank you @samdoran. Merged back into branch redfish_facts.

Thanks @samdoran. The module now accepts more than one category, none (uses default value) or "all" (creates a list of all defined categories).

As per how results are placed, take a look [here](https://github.com/dell/redfish-ansible-module/tree/sample_output_files/sample_output_files_latest). Each set of results in placed separately in a dict.

Thanks again, please let me know where we stand.
Submitted latest updates. Closing PR and reopening to trigger CI.
@samdoran , several patches submitted with your recommendations. Thank you for your review.

I had a look at the code and found two main problems.

The first problem I found is the inability to fetch the information about a specific system and/or manager, since the code only operates on the system/manager that happens to be the last one in the System/Manager collection. I would expect that the facts task would take OData id of the resource that the user would like to inspect.

What also bothers me is the complexity of the user interface of this module, `category` parameter being especially bad. I think it would make much more sense to get rid of the `category` parameter and create a separate ansible module for each category. For example, I feel that this example from the module

    redfish_facts:
      category: Systems
      command: GetCpuInventory
      baseuri: "{{ baseuri }}"
      user: "{{ user }}"
      password: "{{ password }}"

would be much clearer if written as

    redfish_system_facts:
      id: /redfish/v1/Systems/Embedded.1
      command: GetCpuInventory
      baseuri: "{{ baseuri }}"
      user: "{{ user }}"
      password: "{{ password }}"

This will make playbooks a bit more verbose, since we loose the ability to specify more than one category per task. But this limitation would allow us to better define the format of the output. Because informing the user that the result is a dictionary is on par with writing C functions that return `void *` pointers in order to be flexible.

There is quite a few problems still in the code that I have not discussed here (such as adding code that is not used at all at the moment, accessing data that is not mandated by the Redfish standard, creating URLs by hand instead of retrieving them directly from the REST API, using wrong HTTP methods to interface with the Redfish API endpoint, etc.), but I think that those are not as severe as the two I described above.

Disclaimer: I work on integrating Redfish API into ManageIQ and this module is of great interest to me, since most of the automation in ManageIQ is ansible based.

@tadeboro, thank you for your feedback. I am encouraged to see interest and feedback in this module.

On your first major concern, I usually assumed that there would be more than one OData entry (for example, more than one storage controller) and then go through the list, but the code was developed based on hardware I have access to and it's possible something was not covered. Can you please provide a specific example?

On your second major concern, please note that I'm staying away from hard-coding any part of the URIs in the modules *and* playbooks. This module is meant to be vendor-neutral and want to avoid having different playbooks for different vendors. For example, I always assume that the OData ID of `/redfish/v1/Systems` may not always be `/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1`, so `_find_systems_resource()` looks for it.

As for the Category/Command organization, this was meant to simplify (and possibly speed up) the invocation of the `GET/POST/PATCH` calls. It also aligns well with the Redfish API tree structure.

As far as the rest of the code, there is always room for improvement, and once this module is merged upstream, PRs will be welcomed.

Let me close by saying that the DMTF is aware of this module submission (and other 2 waiting in the queue: `redfish_command` and `redfish_config`) and is waiting for merging to add functionality to them.

@samdoran, thanks again for reviewing.

To put the money where my mouth is, I created a minimalistic redfish_system module, available at https://github.com/xlab-si/ansible/commit/27bf15be00d472948efa1c8c5bcb2cf6a63e8070

Utilities module contains a general-purpose Redfish API client with on-demand loading of subresources and caching. redfish_system ansible module contains some demonstration code that shows how to use Redfish client.

I also created a testing playbook that I used to play with the module: https://gist.github.com/tadeboro/00b92bcc8b198dc1e23e4eced8e7efe0

As for the additional functionality, I considered following the OpenStack example where separate parts of the functionality are implemented in `os_<component>` and `os_<component>_facts`. This would allow us to keep the source file sizes manageable and functionality properly separated while still making module easily extendable.

This PoC module is of course only a demonstration, so feel free to ignore it.
@samdoran Thanks for the review, what is next step?

@tadeboro, this code can certainly be improved and optimized, I have added some of your recommendations already and looking forward to merging more. Only way this gets better is by getting helpful, constructive feedback from others. Thanks for your review.
@jose-delarosa As @tadeboro mentioned in his first comment, we are very interested in Redfish module for Ansible. Would you be open for a chat with us on what your plans with the module(s) are?

@gberginc Happy to get on a call next week to discuss. But the ultimate goal is to have the DMTF take ownership of this module (and two more that I will submit once this one is merged upstream). I've been in conversations with them for months and this is one of the projects they want to expand and support.
@samdoran, were you able to reach out to other reviewers to provide a +1 for this request? Do you need any help chasing after them? I can help as needed, thanks.
@tadeboro @gberginc Is this module ok to merge?

Our opinion is that this code needs improvements before it can work, but we do not want to block the merge. I have added several comments regarding code quality, Redfish compliance, etc. In order to use this module, these will have to be addressed in the future.

@tadeboro (with agreement from @gberginc)
rebuild_merge

issues.title: feature request: looping over blocks

labels.name: affects_2.0
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.0

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: feature
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a feature request.

issues.body:
##### Issue Type:

Feature Idea

##### Component Name:
blocks

##### Ansible Version:

Ansible 2.0.0_rc-1
##### Ansible Configuration:

NA
##### Environment:

Ubuntu 15.10

##### Summary of Decision:

We're open to implementing this but want it to go through the proposal process.  Please see: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/13262#issuecomment-335904803 for details.

##### Summary:

There are a number of use-cases where it would be valuable to be able to loop over a block of tasks, such that a few tasks are done in order, and that specific block of tasks are looped over for some set of values. It seems that the new block functionality could lend itself well to this if you were to enable looping over blocks.
##### Steps To Reproduce:

``` yaml
- hosts: localhost
  connection: local
  tasks:
  - block:
    - debug: msg="task 1 loop {{item}}"
    - debug: msg="task 2 loop {{item}}"
    with_items:
    - "1"
    - "2"
```
##### Expected Results:

```
PLAY ***************************************************************************

TASK [setup] *******************************************************************
ok: [localhost]

TASK [debug msg=task 1 loop {{item}}] ******************************************
ok: [localhost] => {
    "changed": false, 
    "msg": "task 1 loop 1"
}

TASK [debug msg=task 2 loop {{item}}] ******************************************
ok: [localhost] => {
    "changed": false, 
    "msg": "task 2 loop 1"
}

TASK [debug msg=task 1 loop {{item}}] ******************************************
ok: [localhost] => {
    "changed": false, 
    "msg": "task 1 loop 2"
}

TASK [debug msg=task 2 loop {{item}}] ******************************************
ok: [localhost] => {
    "changed": false, 
    "msg": "task 2 loop 2"
}

PLAY RECAP *********************************************************************
localhost                  : ok=5    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=0
```
##### Actual Results:

```
ERROR! 'with_items' is not a valid attribute for a Block

The error appears to have been in '/root/test.yml': line 5, column 5, but may
be elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.

The offending line appears to be:

  tasks:
  - block:
    ^ here
```

comments_data.body: you can loop over includes, sorry about the response, I misread this as a bug report
@bcoca I hadn't seen the docs on looping over includes, which seems the better solution than what I have suggested, as my method could quickly result in code that is more difficult to follow.
I want this, because includes are very slow (even after recent fix) and clutter output with full hosts lists and are processed even if skipped (tags).
+1 for this feature.

+1

first thing I tried after installing 2.0, disappointed it doesn't work...
+1 (feature would be very helpful)

+1 
But it should be able to manage tasks with "with_items" so "item" might not be the good keyword here (speaking of the first message).
Looping over an include means you need a new file. Looping over a block is way more cool !
+1, but to prevent naming collisions with `item` from loops, loop from block could be name `block_item`.
+1 **very** interesting feature to work with :+1:
I hate to +1, but I was very sad to discover you can't do this.  As @piotrminkina mentions, block_item would be a good name for the block item.
+1 for the feature. `block_item` sounds like a good keyword in this case
+1 this would be a really useful feature
:+1: I see few possible use-cases for this feature. - It would be really nice to have it.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Postgres pg_hba files are difficult to manage. They can best be related to iptables config:
- first lines hit, will be applied
- there are complexe datatypes involved, like ip addresses and subnets, which could have different notations for the same value.
For these reasons (order is important, complex datatypes), lineinfile doesn't really work well.

On the other hand, templating does work, but overwrite the whole file. Any changes which are there, but are not part of the template, are basically reverted. With Ansible, you can manage only parts of config, but not for pg_hba rules.

This module fixes that. You an state that a hba rule should be there and the modules makes sure it is there and even on the on a logical place, so that it hits, without overriding other rules (other than what should be logical).

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
pg_hba

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
```
ansible 2.4.1.0
  config file = None
  configured module search path = [u'/Users/smannem/.ansible/plugins/modules', u'/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /usr/local/Cellar/ansible/2.4.1.0/libexec/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ansible
  executable location = /usr/local/bin/ansible
  python version = 2.7.14 (default, Sep 25 2017, 09:53:22) [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.0.0 (clang-900.0.37)]
```


##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
This module already was created in juli 2015, and used internally on many occasions. I wanted to commit it to the community,since then, but never took the time too jump through all hoops. It has always been on my personal github account, for anyone to use. I just hope to help others to manag postgres databases in a more transparant way.

After this change, you can
```
ansible -m pg_hba -a 'dest=/tmp/pg_hba.conf contype=host source=192.168.8.0 netmask=255.255.255.0 method=md5 backup=true order=sud state=present create=true'
```

> In order to check if netmask is used with src: all or src: samehost or src: samenet, should not a test be added in main method ?

Instead of a Traceback, the module now returns a clean error with module.fail.
To implement this, I have changed all raises from generic errors to subexceptions of PgHbaException.
Furthermore, in main(), I have used some try/excepts to catch PgHbaException exceptions and run module.fail, returning the message.

Hi Ondra,
I verified those patches with the following playbook (see [1]).

[1]

                  - ovirt_storage_domains:
                          name: "initial_NFS"
                          # TODO: Choose active host in the DC
                          host: "{{ host_name }}"
                          data_center: "{{ item.DC_name }}"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          nfs:
                                  address: "{{ item.address }}"
                                  path: "{{ item.path }}"
                    with_items:
                          - "{{ initial_NFS }}"

                  - ovirt_storage_domains:
                          # TODO: Choose active host in the DC
                          name: "{{ item.name }}"
                          host: "{{ host_name }}"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          data_center: "{{ item.DC_name }}"
                          nfs:
                                  address: "{{ item.address }}"
                                  path: "{{ item.path }}"
                    with_items:
                          - "{{ import_NFS }}"

                            #                  - ovirt_hosts:
                            #                          state: iscsidiscover
                            #                          # TODO: Choose active host in the DC
                            #                          name: "{{ host_name }}"
                            #                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                            #                          iscsi:
                            #                                  username: "{{ item.username }}"
                            #                                  password: "{{ item.password }}"
                            #                                  address: "{{ item.address }}"
                            #                    with_items:
                            #                          - "{{ import_iSCSI }}"

                  - ovirt_hosts:
                          state: iscsilogin
                          # TODO: Choose active host in the DC
                          name: "{{ host_name }}"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          iscsi:
                                  username: "{{ item.0.username }}"
                                  password: "{{ item.0.password }}"
                                  address: "{{ item.0.address }}"
                                  target: "{{ item.1 }}"
                    with_subelements:
                          - "{{ import_iSCSI }}"
                          - target

                  - ovirt_storage_domains:
                          state: 'import'
                          # TODO: Choose predefine host in the block DC
                          id: "{{ item.id }}"
                          name: "{{ item.name }}"
                          host: "{{ host_name }}"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          data_center: "{{ item.DC_name }}"
                          # TODO: For import block there is no need for the iscsi parameters
                          iscsi:
                                  username: "{{ item.username }}"
                                  password: "{{ item.password }}"
                                  address: "{{ item.address }}"
                                  target: "{{ item.target[0] }}"
                    with_items:
                          - "{{ import_iSCSI }}"

                  - ovirt_templates:
                          state: registered
                          storage_domain: "{{ item.storage_domain }}"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          id: "{{ item.id }}"
                          cluster: "{{ item.cluster }}"
                          # TODO: ignore_errors: yes
                    with_items:
                          - "{{ register_templates }}"

                  - ovirt_vms:
                          state: registered
                          storage_domain: "data6"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          name: "VMTest1"
                          cluster: "cluster1"
                          # TODO: ignore_errors: yes

                  - ovirt_vms:
                          state: registered
                          storage_domain: "{{ item.storage_domain }}"
                          id: "{{ item.id }}"
                          auth: "{{ ovirt_auth }}"
                          cluster: "{{ item.cluster }}"
                          # TODO: ignore_errors: yes
                    with_items:
                          - "{{ register_vms }}"

issues.title: Replace the inhouse collection dependency resolver with `resolvelib`

labels.name: test
labels.description: This PR relates to tests.

labels.name: core_review
labels.description: In order to be merged, this PR must follow the core review workflow.

labels.name: support:community
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible community.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: docs
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to or includes documentation.

labels.name: feature
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a feature request.

labels.name: docsite
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to the documentation website.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change below, including rationale and design decisions -->
This change replaces our in-tree dependency resolution with external `resolvelib` that comes from the pip ecosystem. In doing so, it substantially refactors `ansible-galaxy collection [download|install|list|verify]` subcommands.

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest -->
- Feature Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Write the short name of the module, plugin, task or feature below -->
galaxy cli

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!--- Include additional information to help people understand the change here -->
<!--- A step-by-step reproduction of the problem is helpful if there is no related issue -->

~Sanity checks blocker: https://github.com/ansible-community/antsibull/issues/217~

This PR does not fully address #71784.

issues.title: Collection content loading

labels.name: new_plugin
labels.description: This PR includes a new plugin.

labels.name: support:community
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible community.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: feature

labels.name: collection
labels.description: Related to Ansible Collections work

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Load content and plugins from installed Ansible collections.

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Feature Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
PluginLoader

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
**KNOWN ISSUES:**
* Plugin types not yet tested: become, cache, cliconf, doc_fragments, httpapi, Powershell module_utils, netconf, shell, strategy, terminal, vars
* plugin_loader's `all()` method isn't collection-aware (so eg, ansible-doc can't see these yet)
* error messaging on load failures varies widely (from nonexistent to meh)
* inventory plugin `NAME` must currently be FQNS (eg `mynamespace.mycollection.invpluginname`)
* Python modules must currently import ansible.module_utils.basic if they import any other module_utils (bug)
* collection module_utils imports can't currently do non-granular Python module imports with `from`. eg, `from ansible_collections.myns.mycoll.plugins.module_utils import module` won't work, but `from ansible_collections.myns.mycoll.plugins.module_utils.module import stuff` will. (bug)
* role deduplication does not (yet) take the fully-qualified role name into account, so something like
```
- roles: [myns.mycoll.role_a, otherns.othercoll.role_a]
```
will not execute the second role unless `allow_duplicates` is set (bug)

**NON-DOCUMENTATION:**
Uses the new installed_content_roots config value to load spec-compliant collection content (defaults to playbook-adjacent/collections, then `~/.ansible/collections`, `/usr/share/ansible/collections` in that order).

Structure underneath an installed content dir is a Python 3.x implicit namespace package, set up as a subpackage of `ansible_collections` (the root Python namespace for all this stuff).

Once content is installed, most plugin types can be referenced as usual in Ansible by `namespace.collection_name.plugin_name` (except module_utils, which require the fully-qualified `ansible_collections.namespace.collection_name.plugins.module_utils.module_name` syntax). eg:
playbook.yaml
```
...
tasks:
- mynamespace.mycollection.mymodule:
    args: #...
- mynamespace.othercollection.myaction:
    args: #...
- assert:
    that:
    - 'foo' | mynamespace.mycollection.myfiltername == 'foofiltered'
    - 'foo' is mynamespace.mycollection.mytest
    - lookup('mynamespace.mycollection.mylookup', 'foo') == 'looked up foo'
```

inventory_config.yaml
```
plugin: mynamespace.mycollection.myinventory_plugin
...
```

ansible.cfg
```
[defaults]
callback_whitelist=mynamespace.mycollection.mycallback
```

hosts
```
myhost ansible_connection=mynamespace.mycollection.myconnection_plugin
```

**SYNTHETIC COLLECTIONS**
Two "fake" collections are included, `ansible.builtin` and `ansible.legacy`. `ansible.builtin` can be used as a prefix to load any plugin shipped inside the Ansible distribution (but *not* legacy extension dirs like `library`, `action_plugins`, etc). `ansible.legacy` behaves the same as `ansible.builtin`, but will also fall back to loading items from the legacy extension dirs (in most cases- collection-hosted roles are special). eg
```
- ping: # execute the built-in `ping` module, unless it was overridden by something in a `library/` dir
- ansible.builtin.ping: # execute the built-in `ping` module, ignoring any `library` dirs
- ansible.legacy.ping: # same as `ping`
```

**`collections` KEYWORD AND UNQUALIFIED MODULES/ACTIONS**
By default, any unqualified action/module in a task (meaning no namespace + collection name prefix specified) is assumed to be a built-in module/action or loadable from a legacy library/action_plugins path (ie the way Ansible has always worked). This behavior can be altered by adding the `collections` keyword at the play/block/task level with an ordered list of collections to be searched for unqualified modules/actions. eg, in the following playbook:
```
- hosts: localhost
  collections:
  - ansible.builtin
  - myns.mycoll
  tasks:
  - mymodule:
```
when the action resolver is trying to find the implementation of `mymodule`, it will first check the built-in actions and modules, then the `myns.mycoll` collection (and since we used `ansible.builtin`, it will ignore any legacy extension `library/` or `action_plugins/` dirs outside the `myns.mycoll` collection). 

If `ansible.builtin` or `ansible.legacy` does not appear in the `collections` list, `ansible.legacy` will be appended to the end of the list to ease adding collection search behavior to existing content.

**ROLES AND COLLECTIONS**

Roles do not inherit `collections` search paths configured by the play. Role content is assumed to have been authored to work with a specific set of plugins, so the calling playbook should not be able to alter those assumptions. Roles in a collection (ie roles under the collection's `roles` dir) will not load plugins from any legacy plugin dirs inside the role (eg `library`, `action_plugins`), nor from playbook-adjacent or configured role paths (by default, but this one can be changed if the legacy behavior is desired). Roles in a collection are configured with a default collection search path of:
```
- (the role's collection)
- ansible.builtin
```
Role collections search behavior can be further altered by using the `collections` keyword on a block or task, or by setting a list of collections to search in the role's `meta/main.yml` using the new `collections` role meta keyword. The current collection will always be prepended to the list specified, and `ansible.builtin` will always be appended to the end unless it or `ansible.legacy` is specified explicitly somewhere else in the list.

> Uses the new installed_content_roots config value to load spec-compliant collection content (defaults to playbook adjacent dir "plugin_content", ~/.ansible/content`, `/usr/share/ansible/content`in that order- playbook-adjacent dir will eventually just be`content`).

Since 'content' was the term used before we the term 'collections' started being used, I would suggest changing the use of 'content' in paths to 'collections'.

For ex, in:
- ~/.ansible/content -> ~/.ansible/collections
- <some_playbook_project>/plugin_content -> <some_playbook_project>/collections
- /usr/share/ansible/content -> /usr/share/ansible/collections

installed_content_roots -> installed_collection_roots  (or 'collection_paths' or 'collection_dirs' etc)

That leaves 'content' open for future use, while reinforcing the idea that this support is for 'collections' specifically.
Will role loading be part of this pr or a separate pr?

Testing with the collection at https://github.com/alikins/collection_inspect  / https://galaxy-dev.ansible.com/alikins/collection_inspect

@alikins ah, I think I see the confusion. The root of the entire "installed" managed content dir should be the `a` package, with namespace + collection subpackages below. eg:
```
└── a
    ├── __init__.py
    └── mynamespace
        ├── aws
        │   ├── __init__.py
        │   └── plugins
        │       ├── __init__.py
        │       ├── inventory
        │       │   └── __init__.py
        │       ├── modules
        │       │   └── __init__.py
        │       └── module_utils
        │           └── __init__.py
        ├── __init__.py
        └── mycollection
            ├── __init__.py
            └── plugins
                ├── action
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── callback
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── connection
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── filter
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── __init__.py
                ├── inventory
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── lookup
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── modules
                │   └── __init__.py
                ├── module_utils
                │   └── __init__.py
                └── test
                    └── __init__.py
```

So the github root of a collection would just be the what's under the "mycollection" level, leaving `mazer` et al responsible for managing the structure above it. Make sense?

... and if you want to split a namespace between system/user/content-adjacent, the __init__ under the `a` and namespace packages currently needs to include the extend_paths boilerplate above. I've already worked around that with dynamic packages, just haven't integrated the change into this tree yet.

I'm all for changing the top-level directory name to `collections` from `content` if @thaumos/@tima agree.

And yes, my plan is to include the role-loading in this branch as well once the plugin stuff gets to an MVPish state.

@nitzmahone 

> The root of the entire "installed" managed content dir should be the a package, with namespace + collection subpackages below.

> I'm all for changing the top-level directory name to `collections` from `content` if @thaumos/@tima agree.

Maybe we can combine those two needs and rename the 'content' dir (ie, ~/.ansible/content) to something like 'ansible_collections'[1], and let 'ansible_collections' also be the python namespace root instead of the current 'a'. ?

[1] or 'ansiblecollections' or 'galaxy_collections' etc
@alikins what is the future use of content you have in mind? What is gained by reinforcing collections to the end user?
Yeah, let's change it to collections @nitzmahone.  It is simple enough.  No need to bikeshed on this.

<!--- boilerplate: shippable_test_result --->

- needs tests (at some point, if not this pr)
- needs docs (at some point)

Some existing code in module_common.py can miss the case where 'from ansible_collections' is used, especially if there is no use of 'from ansible.module_utils'. This causes the collection based module_utils to not be included in the anziballZ.

Possible fix at https://github.com/alikins/ansible/commits/pr-52194-fixes  in  https://github.com/alikins/ansible/commit/e12571313ad36c101c6a894f197f1893129d4401

> Plugin types not implemented/tested: become, cache, cliconf, doc_fragments, httpapi, Powershell module_utils, netconf, shell, strategy, terminal, vars

module_utils seems to work mostly in my testing. The main tricky part is that imports that import an entire py module from module_utils fail (```from ansible_collections.alikins.collection_inspect.plugins.module_utils import collection_inspect```), while imports from a py module work (```from ansible_collections.alikins.collection_inspect.plugins.module_utils.collection_inspect import get_dunders_method```). 

Or, in other words, imports from a py module file works, imports from a py package fail.
There are FIXME's about this in the module_common code and this is known, but noting here for prosperity.

> Plugin types not implemented/tested: become, cache, cliconf, doc_fragments, httpapi, Powershell module_utils, netconf, shell, strategy, terminal, vars

As of cc741706cf840dc0d780fced1cdd671a2b8c029a, my testing seems to confirm that at least 'vars' plugins don't seem to work yet. Afaict, nothing ever attempts to find/load them.
@alikins that should happen for every task as they call vars manager

issues.body:
<!--- Verify first that your issue is not already reported on GitHub -->
<!--- Also test if the latest release and devel branch are affected too -->
<!--- Complete *all* sections as described, this form is processed automatically -->

##### SUMMARY
Issue with one of our components where in the file system says not available even though the device is available (via Ansible)

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
task

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from "ansible --version" between quotes -->
```paste below
ansible 2.8.5
  config file = None
  configured module search path = [u'/root/.ansible/plugins/modules', u'/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ansible
  executable location = /bin/ansible
```

##### CONFIGURATION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from "ansible-config dump --only-changed" between quotes -->
```paste below
none
```

##### OS / ENVIRONMENT
RHEL 7


##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!--- Describe exactly how to reproduce the problem, using a minimal test-case -->

<!--- Paste example playbooks or commands between quotes below -->
```yaml
- set_fact:
    device: /dev/nvme2n1
  when: nvmedev.stat.exists == True
Then attach / mount the volumes as (e.g. vol-a) using 

- name: Attach the existing cold summaries volume if it is found
  ec2_vol:
    id: "{{ ec2_vol_data_cold_summaries.volumes[0].id }}"
    instance: "{{ ansible_ec2_instance_identity_document_instanceid }}"
    device_name: "/dev/xvdf"
    region: "{{ ansible_ec2_instance_identity_document_region }}"
  when: ec2_vol_data_cold_summaries.volumes|length > 0

mount:
    path: /var/cold_summaries
    src: "{{ device }}"
    fstype: ext4
    state: mounted
    opts: noatime
```

<!--- HINT: You can paste gist.github.com links for larger files -->

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
<!--- Describe what you expected to happen when running the steps above -->


##### ACTUAL RESULTS
<!--- Describe what actually happened. If possible run with extra verbosity (-vvvv) -->

<!--- Paste verbatim command output between quotes -->
```paste below
We are having an issue with one of our components where in the file system says not available even though the device is available (via Ansible).
The instance is spinned up and via ansible we set the facts like 
- set_fact:
    device: /dev/nvme2n1
  when: nvmedev.stat.exists == True
Then attach / mount the volumes as (e.g. vol-a) using 

- name: Attach the existing cold summaries volume if it is found
  ec2_vol:
    id: "{{ ec2_vol_data_cold_summaries.volumes[0].id }}"
    instance: "{{ ansible_ec2_instance_identity_document_instanceid }}"
    device_name: "/dev/xvdf"
    region: "{{ ansible_ec2_instance_identity_document_region }}"
  when: ec2_vol_data_cold_summaries.volumes|length > 0

mount:
    path: /var/cold_summaries
    src: "{{ device }}"
    fstype: ext4
    state: mounted
    opts: noatime
We get the error as below:

TASK [indexer : Mount the volume] *******************************
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "Error mounting /var/cold_summaries: mount: special device /dev/nvme2n1 does not exist\n"}


NAME        MAJ:MIN RM SIZE RO TYPE MOUNTPOINT
nvme0n1     259:1    0   4G  0 disk
└─nvme0n1p1 259:2    0   4G  0 part /
nvme1n1     259:0    0  50G  0 disk /opt/
nvme2n1     259:3    0  16T  0 disk


and when I manually mount using mount devicename filesystemname (as below) it works fine.

mount /dev/nvme2n1 /var/cold_summaries
```

I have no idea why errors occurred related with queries to replication stat tables when I pushed the commit with integration tests.
On my local machine it was done in the docker container well..
```
test/runner/ansible-test integration --docker-no-pull --docker fedora28 -v postgresql >> ~/test.log
```
I added info in the module documentation that PostgreSQL must be 9.4 version or later (replication slots were added since this version). And would better to remain information about it
@mattclay @dagwieers what must I do to pass this ansibot tests well?

@Andersson007 You will have to look at the Shippable CI details and see why it failed for some of the test environments. This is the one for CentOS-6.
```
04:19 The full traceback is:
04:19 Traceback (most recent call last):
04:19   File "/tmp/ansible_postgresql_facts_payload_V_geHv/__main__.py", line 475, in __exec_sql
04:19     self.cursor.execute(query)
04:19   File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/psycopg2/extras.py", line 118, in execute
04:19     return _cursor.execute(self, query, vars, async)
04:19 ProgrammingError: relation "pg_stat_replication" does not exist
04:19 LINE 1: ...ent_hostname, r.backend_start::text, r.state FROM pg_stat_re...
04:19                                                              ^
```
The problem is the same for CentOS-7, RHEL-7 and Ubuntu 14.04.

@dagwieers , pg_stat_replication table is the system Postgres table that contents replication statistics and it was added in 9.1 Postgres server version (very old). Ok, I'm trying to add some checks in module to pass this table, if it doesn't exists.
ready_for_review

Can the return facts be documented ? It really adds value if users can see what facts are returned.

For example see: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/modules/win_disk_facts_module.html#returned-facts
@dagwieers , it sounds really good

The main problem is that from a version to a version the postgres developers adds really interesting columns to the statistics tables. It's a problem for ansible development and it's a useful feature for DBAs. I can't test it locally (becouse I haven't infrastructure with servers with all of postgres versions) so I need to test it here...

The test `ansible-test sanity --test no-smart-quotes` [[explain](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/testing/sanity/no-smart-quotes.html)] failed with 1 error:
```
lib/ansible/modules/database/postgresql/postgresql_facts.py:318:63: use ASCII quotes `'` and `"` instead of Unicode quotes
```
<!-- job_id: 5c59813ea2f6de07009c67d2 -->
<!-- job_id: 5c598145bf2f560800e4146b -->
<!-- job_id: /testresults/ansible-test-sanity-no-smart-quotes.json -->

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: shippable_test_result --->

@dagwieers , done for all of your notices.

And I also made param names shorter: include_subset => incl_subset, exclude_subset => excl_subset

It was difficult but I've got a lot of valuable experience to implement this ;)
FYI: Unfortunately, I needed to make force push.
ready_for_review

So regarding the `incl_subset` and `excl_subset` the standard way of doing this in facts-modules is to have a `gather_subset` parameter that includes the subsets you want to include, and it defaults to `all`.

So this would replace the other two parameters by a single one. Recursively grep for `gather_subset` in your modules-directory and you'll see how other modules do this.

Example: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/modules/setup_module.html#parameters

@dagwieers , seems I've done changes. The key points are:
1. I understood that there aren't any subsets in postgresql_facts...
gather_subset doesn't make sense in this module because the full set of facts quite small.
In the meaning of like in https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/setup_module.html 
incl_subsets / excl_subsets was just a filter (like the "filter=someparam*" in setup module).
I changed it to "filter=". See examples in the topic.
2. I formatted it as you requested.
3. I left 'usename' as it was.
It was hard work but it gave me a lot of valuable experience.
ready_for_review

issues.body:
now it can scan for multiple package managers per system
  also added portage support

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest -->
- Feature Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Write the short name of the module, plugin, task or feature below -->
scan_packages

comments_data.body:
Hi @bcoca, thank you for submitting this pull-request!

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: thank_submitter --->

cc @mattclay
[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: notify --->

This makes it hard to program against the return values as the fields as heterogeneous using this.  Need to think of a better structure for the return values so that we only have packages with the same fields together.

I was thinking of enforcing a 'minimal' structure (mandatory: name, version, source) and leaving the rest variable as the different systems provide data that might interest some and not others, but even then try to normalize as much as possible (optional: category, origin, auto, etc).
I think you were right to  use @abstractmethod.  You just have to use it correctly.  (The toplevel class in the hierarchy should be using six.with_metaclass=ABCMeta)

Three global thoughts:

* For the return values, I think that a minimal structure has benefits and would be sufficient if the module wasn't returning values from multiple package managers in the same invocation.  However, since you're now having the module return packages from multiple package managers, it no longer is sufficient.  A person can no longer iterate the list of packages and know what fields they are going to encounter, even in an environment which has heterogeneous platforms.  So if we're going to allow this we need to separate the values that differ per package manager.  Maybe pip_package[], rpm_package[], etc (possibly with a return value that combines all of them in addition?)

* Errors, there's a few cornercases around errors.  Trying to step back far enough to find a general rul... perhaps we want to return errors if anything that the user specified as an explicit package manager type failed and return warnings for anything that was pulled in via auto?

* non-system package managers: If we expand this to non-system package managers like pip, then we have multiple package managers of *a single type*.  For instance, we'd need to account for /usr/bin/pip2.7 /usr/bin/pip3.6 and /usr/bin/pip3.7 all being installed on the same system.  Should we avoid non-system package managers in this module for the moment?

- For the return values, you always have 'souce' which will indicate the fields provided, very similar as what you propose. I left it as is to avoid changing the general format and those already using the module won't have to change anything

- The errors i'm still 'evolving' on how to handle, displaying only for explicit sounds good, we'll probably iterate more over this as we get user feedback

- I added pip mostly as example .. but it does have issues with different python interpreters and `--user flag`, also this would change the classification of the plugin itself `packaging/os` ... so i'm fine with dropping it for now or revisiting the interface (allow overriding of the cli searched?).

So there seems to be several changes in this single PR... here's what I think about each:
* Adding portage +1
* refactoring the code into modular pieces based on classes +1
* Adding the ability to read from multiple package managers -1
  * This feature would be okay if the return values were changed to separate the packages from different package managers into separate output fields for each manager.  But without that we'd be shoving nonheterogeneous output into a single return field which isn't the right way to do things.
  * sivel also raises the problem that strategy will cause us to need to namespace the results further.  I agree with that assessment for strategy.  Changing the return value to have separate fields for each manager would solve this problem as well as we could get rid of strategy altogether and return output from all managers everytime.

except that breaks backwards compatibility with existing playbooks, as is the defaults will still work as they did before. You only have collision issues if you keep mismatching lists, but that is up to the user and we can document it as a consideration, which already exists for most facts modules, including setup.

cc @matburt @maxamillion
[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)

issues.title: [openssh/linux kernel > 3.12] Intermittent error "failed to resolve remote temporary directory from" [sleep 0]

labels.name: needs_info
labels.description: This issue requires further information. Please answer any outstanding questions.

labels.name: affects_2.2
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.2

labels.name: affects_2.3
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.3

labels.name: needs_template
labels.description: This issue/PR has an incomplete description. Please fill in the proposed template correctly.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a bug.

issues.body:
After I upgrade ansible 2.0.0.1 from 1.9.4, when performing a playlook always encounter intermittent fault "failed to resolve remote temporary directory from".

```
$ ansible-playbook playlooks/playlook-filters.yml

PLAY ***************************************************************************

TASK [command] *****************************************************************
fatal: [YT_8_22]: FAILED! => {"failed": true, "msg": "ERROR! failed to resolve remote temporary directory from ansible-tmp-1452759681.1-95441304852350: `( umask 22 && mkdir -p \"$( echo /tmp/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1452759681.1-95441304852350 )\" && echo \"$( echo /tmp/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1452759681.1-95441304852350 )\" )` returned empty string"}
...ignoring

TASK [debug] *******************************************************************
ok: [YT_8_22] => {
    "msg": "it failed"
}

PLAY RECAP *********************************************************************
YT_8_22                    : ok=2    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=0
```

This is happening for one of the tasks randomly, following are those tasks:

```

---
- hosts: YT_8_22
  tasks:
    - shell: /bin/true
      register: result
      ignore_errors: True

    - debug: msg="it failed"
      when: result|failed
```

I try on 1.9.4, have not seen the phenomenon. Can anybody tell me how to do that ?

I found another links to similar problems: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/ansible-project/Intermittent$20error%7Csort:relevance/ansible-project/FyK6au2O9KY/tWuf31P9AQAJ

comments_data.body:
Hi there, 
I also cough that with `-vvvv` flag. 

```
<45.56.96.138> ESTABLISH SSH CONNECTION FOR USER: root
<45.56.96.138> SSH: EXEC ssh -C -vvv -o ControlMaster=auto -o ControlPersist=60s -o 'IdentityFile="/home/riversy/.ssh/id_rsa"' -o KbdInteractiveAuthentication=no -o PreferredAuthentications=gssapi-with-mic,gssapi-keyex,hostbased,publickey -o PasswordAuthentication=no -o User=root -o ConnectTimeout=10 -o ControlPath=/home/riversy/.ansible/cp/ansible-ssh-%h-%p-%r -tt 45.56.96.138 'mkdir -p "$( echo $HOME/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1453707878.36-19081627291623 )" && echo "$( echo $HOME/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1453707878.36-19081627291623 )"'
fatal: [45.56.96.138]: FAILED! => {"failed": true, "msg": "ERROR! failed to resolve remote temporary directory from ansible-tmp-1453707878.36-19081627291623: `mkdir -p \"$( echo $HOME/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1453707878.36-19081627291623 )\" && echo \"$( echo $HOME/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1453707878.36-19081627291623 )\"` returned empty string"}
```

My version of ansible is:

```
ansible 2.0.0.2
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
```

Will be appreciate for any advice. 

Update: Sometimes it also happens even on: `ansible all -i inventory/test -m ping` command.

I have noticed that if I run a playbook back to back I generally get success.

IE

Run #1: 
fatal: [1.2.3.4]: FAILED! => {"failed": true, "msg": "failed to resolve remote temporary directory from ansible-tmp-1453754269.23-53039386122234: `( umask 22 && mkdir -p \"$( echo $HOME/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1453754269.23-53039386122234 )\" && echo \"$( echo $HOME/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1453754269.23-53039386122234 )\" )` returned empty string"}

Run #2: Success

However waiting ~ a minute the failure will occur again.  Monitoring the remote machine I do not see the ~/.ansible/tmp/<dir> being created when an error condition is reached.  So it seems the error is truly valid, the question is what is preventing that directory from being created.  This issue only started after upgrading to 2.0.0 (also tried 2.0.0.2-1)

Also started experiencing the error after upgrading from Ansible 1.9.4 to 2.0.0.2. 

Doubt it matters, but just in case it's a CentOS 7.1 VPS hosted on Linode.

I encountered this on random shell/command tasks in a playbook against a CentOS vps on amazon. That's our only CentOS 7.2 machine with 20+ other amazon ami servers which haven't shown the issue so far. 

I tried 2.0.0, 2.0.0.2, 2.1, pipelining on/off, controlpersist on/off, and running from OS X / amazon ami. I also tried removing the .ansible files from the target node with no effect 

This might not be related, but I ended up resolving this issue for now by restarting the machine. I had noticed logs like this mentioned a corrupted btmp log, and executed 'cat /dev/null > /var/log/btmp', followed by a restart. The btmp thing might not be related, but it was logging on every ansible command/connection. I had moved my /var partition to a different disk the day before, it's possible it became corrupted from that. 

 sshd[24031]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session closed for user centos
sshd[24248]: Accepted publickey for centos from  port 45694 ssh2: 
sshd[24248]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user centos by (uid=0)
sshd[24248]: pam_lastlog(sshd:session): corruption detected in /var/log/btmp
sshd[24251]: Received disconnect from : 11: disconnected by user

@mgaley based on your feedback I looked into the ssh connection to my client and found something interesting.

I am using RHEL 6.6 for both source and destination machines and Ansible 2.0.0.2

Remoteserver#> tail -f /var/log/secure

Jan 27 07:47:48 Remoteserver sshd[19329]: Accepted publickey for jenkins from Ansiblehost port 41384 ssh2
Jan 27 07:47:48 Remoteserver sshd[19329]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user jenkins by (uid=0)

<< --- >>
Ansibleserver: ERROR! failed to resolve remote temporary directory

SSH Connection remains established by the Ansible PID (but not the original pid that opens it, I assume this is expected)

Running again within the 60s window where the connection remains established produced my above result of success

"ControlPersist=60s"
<<-->>
Retry playbook (previous Established SSH session is used)

Jan 27 07:48:11 Remoteserver sshd[19333]: subsystem request for sftp
Jan 27 07:48:12 Remoteserver sshd[19333]: subsystem request for sftp
Jan 27 07:49:13 Remoteserver sshd[19333]: Received disconnect from Ansiblehost: 11: disconnected by user
Jan 27 07:49:13 Remoteserver sshd[19329]: pam_unix(sshd:session): session closed for user jenkins

Playbook completes successfully.

I see the same issue as well running 
ansible 2.1.0 (devel 4b1d621442) last updated 2016/01/28 19:20:32 (GMT -400)

I also had the same issue when using the same playbook against 5 amazon ami servers in 5 separate blocks of a play, only against the first node though. Didn't see anything related in the secure log this time. 

Only in related to shell/command modules, running multiple playbooks at the same time locally, even to the same remote hosts didn't cause the error to happen any more often.
We get this as well. Interesting to note https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/ansible-devel/5i6VDHKZ30I/0ksVpEEICwAJ the possibility of a race condition in dir creation?

I'm seeing this too. It appears to happen randomly on arbitrary tasks in a playbook, always regarding this tmp file stuff. I just re-run the playbook until it works. I am using a network filesystem (rackspace block storage).
Happens to me as well. Truly random it seems.

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/200f95887373e215eb41adb3dcc4128a0a0e0f88/lib/ansible/plugins/action/__init__.py

There are two issues here. 
1. Don't use the fall through like setting rc to / in order to flag something has gone wrong. The error handling approach in this file is faulty. My opinion - discuss!
2. In the function _make_tmp_path we find what I think is the root cause and why running the playbook twice fixes the issue. I suspect, though I have not confirmed, this never occurs more than once on any given server.

I suspect something to do with how function mkdtemp  in file https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/42e312d3bd0516ceaf2b4533ac643bd9e05163cd/lib/ansible/plugins/shell/sh.py works.

Anyone feel I'm completely on the wrong track?
+1 getting the same issue. Really random

I'm getting the same, using archlinux vagrant controller and archlinux vagrant targets.
All boxes are on ansible v 2.0.0.2

This is caused by a bug in the Linux kernel or in openssh, not sure which one is at fault.
https://bugzilla.mindrot.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2492
https://lkml.org/lkml/2015/12/9/775

One workaround is to downgrade the linux kernel on the server to a version that does not include commit 1a48632ffed61352a7810ce089dc5a8bcd505a60. For Ubuntu 14.04 this is e.g. 3.16.0-60, or 3.19.0-22 or earlier.
I am running kernel 2.6.32-504 (rhel 6.6). And this bug only occurs on Ansible 2.x not previous versions.
I'm using kernel 4.3.3-3-ARCH and am not interested in going back to 3.x kernels on these machines.

Another workaround would be using a different transport other than Openssh (paramiko?).

I'm going to close this ticket as Ansible itself is not doing anything wrong here, this is just a bad interaction between tools we depend on.

Why did it only start appearing after folks switched from Ansible 1.9.x to Ansible 2.0.x? 

Not disputing that it's not an issue with the underlying tools, just genuinely curious why it wasn't an issue before.

I'm not sure how this is considered resolved... @rpsiv confirmed it happens with older kernels as well, so not a kernel bug. It didn't happen for anyone before Ansible 2.0.x and now it's widespread.

> between tools we depend on

Which are these tools that you're referring to @bcoca ? I'd be happy to find the root cause and help it get fixed by working with other open source teams, however at this point it's not clear to me where should I (we) begin? Thanks.

##### SUMMARY
Bug fixes for GCP (as of 2019-11-13T07:04:50+00:00)
This PR is the result of the following Magic Modules PRs:
  - [Filter lists of TF schema paths for included properties](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2690)
  - [set value for enabled in network_policy block in tests](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2689)
  - [remove unused variable for compute instance lint](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2688)
  - [remove TestAccContainerCluster_withReleaseChannelDefault as it no longer tests a valid config](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2687)
  - [Fix regex in health check tests](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2686)
  - [Revert access.role field in bigquery dataset to optional](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2684)
  - [Compute Instance Datasource test fix](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2683)
  - [update hand written docs to reflect newly required fields](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2682)
  - [Delete subnet id_format, use default.](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2681)
  - [Paddy drop pgp key](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2680)
  - [TPG 3.0.0](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2679)
  - [TPG 3.0.0](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/magic-modules/pull/2470)

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Bugfix Pull Request

labels.description: Crypto community (ACME, openssl, letsencrypt)

issues.body:
New module that uses `cryptsetup` (LUKS) functions for management of encrypted devices.
Supports creation/removing/locking/unlocking of LUKS containers as well as adding and removing of additional keys. Unit tests included.
This module is needed for storage operations with encrypted devices.

##### ISSUE TYPE
- New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
luks_device

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Ensure that your keyfiles are protected.

@japokorn thanks for your PR!

Could you please fix the issues with the sanity checks?

Some general comments:
 - Why not name this module `luks_device` instead of `crypt_device`? `crypt_device` sounds very generic.
 - You recommend to use Ansible Vault, but require the keys to be written to disk. It would be useful to be able to provide the keys directly via the playbook (encrypted by Vault or not), so that they are directly piped into `cryptsetup` without being written to disk (`cryptsetup` supports that).

Which modules do you mean? Every module I checked uses `choices` in `argument_spec` if it is used in the documentation.

>     2. `E121 continuation line under-indented for hanging indent` It is not possible to indent these ifs so PEP8 doesn't complain. No way described in PEP8 documentation works nor any other one I could come up with.

Can you try this?
``` .py
         if (self._module.params['device'] is None or
                self._module.params['key'] is None or
                self._module.params['open'] is False):
            # conditions for open not fulfilled
            return False 
```

BTW, if you install flake8 on your machine (`pip install flake8`), you can run `flake8 /path/to/your/module.py` and get (almost) instant feedback on PEP8 issues.

> Please check your CI settings or let me know what to do to make it work. Thanks.

<!--- boilerplate: shippable_test_result --->

One general remark: instead of having `state` (`present`/`absent`) and `open` (`true`/`false`), why not have four values for `state`? I.e. `present`, `opened`, `closed`, and `absent`? `present` simply makes sure it is there (and doesn't care about being open or closed), `opened` and `closed` imply `present`, and `absent` makes sure it is closed and wiped? This would simplify logic a bit (and avoid errors such as `Contradiction in setup: LUKS set to be 'absent' and 'open'.`).

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
Add or remove PostgreSQL sequence from remote hosts.

##### ISSUE TYPE
- New Module Pull Request

##### MAIN OPTIONS

- sequence: The name (optionally schema-qualified) of the sequence.
- state: absent | present
- data_type: Specifies the data type of the sequence. Valid types are smallint, integer, and bigint. bigint is the default. The data type determines the default minimum and maximum values of the sequence. Supported from PostgreSQL 10.
- increment: Increment specifies which value is added to the current sequence value to create a new value.
- minvalue: Minvalue determines the minimum value a sequence can generate.
- maxvalue: Maxvalue determines the maximum value for the sequence.
- start: Start allows the sequence to begin anywhere.
- cache: Cache specifies how many sequence numbers are to be preallocated and stored in memory for faster access.
- cycle: The cycle option allows the sequence to wrap around when the maxvalue or minvalue has been reached by an ascending or descending sequence respectively.
- cascade: Automatically drop objects that depend on the sequence, and in turn all objects that depend on those objects.
- restrict: Refuse to drop the sequence if any objects depend on it. This is the default.
- rename: The new name for the sequence.
- schema: The schema in the new sequence will be created.
- newschema: The new schema for the sequence.
- session_role: Switch to session_role after connecting.
...

##### RETURN
```
state:
  description: Sequence state at the end of execution.
  returned: always
  type: str
  sample: 'present'
sequence:
  description: Sequence name.
  returned: always
  type: str
  sample: 'foobar'
queries:
    description: List of queries that was tried to be executed.
    returned: always
    type: str
    sample: [ "CREATE SEQUENCE \"foo\"" ]
schema:
    description: Name of the schema of the sequence
    returned: always
    type: str
    sample: 'foo'
data_type:
    description:
    returned: always
    samlpe: 'bigint'
increment:
    description: The value of increment of the sequence. A positive value will make
                 an ascending sequence, a negative one a descending sequence.
    returned: always
    samlpe: '-1'
minvalue:
    description: The value of minvalue of the sequence.
    returned: always
    samlpe: '1'
maxvalue:
    description: The value of maxvalue of the sequence.
    returned: always
    samlpe: '9223372036854775807'
start:
    description: The value of start of the sequence.
    returned: always
    samlpe: '12'
cycle:
    description: Shows if the sequence cycle or not.
    returned: always
    samlpe: 'NO'
owner:
    description: Shows the current owner of the sequence.
    returned: always
    samlpe: 'postgres'
newname:
    description: Shows the new sequence name after rename.
    returned: on success
    samlpe: 'barfoo'
newschema:
    description: Shows the new schema of the sequence after schema change.
    returned: on success
    samlpe: 'foobar'
```

##### OUTPUT EXAMPLE
**Task:**
```
- name: postgresql_sequence - create an descending sequence called foobar_desc, starting at 101 and which cycle between 1 to 1000
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar_desc
    increment: -1
    start: 101
    minvalue: 1
    maxvalue: 1000
    cycle: yes
```
**Output:**
```
changed: [testhost] => {
    "changed": true,
    "cycle": "YES",
    "data_type": "bigint",
    "increment": "-1",
    "invocation": {
        "module_args": {
            "ca_cert": null,
            "cache": null,
            "cascade": null,
            "cycle": true,
            "data_type": null,
            "db": "ansible_db",
            "increment": -1,
            "login_host": "",
            "login_password": "",
            "login_unix_socket": "",
            "login_user": "postgres",
            "maxvalue": 1000,
            "minvalue": 1,
            "name": "foobar_desc",
            "newschema": null,
            "owner": null,
            "port": 5432,
            "rename_to": null,
            "restrict": null,
            "schema": null,
            "sequence": "foobar_desc",
            "session_role": null,
            "ssl_mode": "prefer",
            "start": 101,
            "state": "present"
        }
    },
    "maxvalue": "1000",
    "minvalue": "1",
    "owner": "postgres",
    "queries": [
        "CREATE SEQUENCE \"foobar_desc\" INCREMENT BY -1 MINVALUE 1 MAXVALUE 1000 START WITH 101 CYCLE"
    ],
    "schema": "public",
    "sequence": "foobar_desc",
    "start": "101",
    "state": "present"
}
```

##### EXAMPLES
```
- name: Create an ascending sequence called foobar
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar

- name: Create an ascending sequence called foobar, starting at 101
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar
    start: 101

- name: Create an descending sequence called foobar, starting at 101
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar
    increment: -1
    start: 101

- name: Create an ascending sequence called foobar, which cycle between 1 to 10
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar
    cycle: yes
    min: 1
    max: 10

- name: Rename an existing sequence named foo to bar
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foo
    rename_to: bar

- name: Change the schema of an existing sequence to foobar
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar
    newschema: foobar

- name: Drop a sequence called foobar
  postgresql_sequence:
    name: foobar
    state: absent
```

issues.body:
Added cyberarkpassword lookup plugin: It allows to retrieve credentials
(password, sshkey) from CyberArk Digital Vault

Added Modules:
- cyberark_authentication: Logon/Logoff to CyberArk Vault
- cyberark_user: user management

These 2 modules use CyberArk Privileged Account Security Web Services
SDK

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY

Fixes #28159

A new module to manage subscription-manager repositories based on the discussion reported in #28159 based on the comment https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/28159#issuecomment-322184760 https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/28159#issuecomment-322184773 a new module called "redhat_repository" to go alongside "redhat_subscription" has been created. 

It allows to list enabled/disable/all repositories
It allows to execute the needs described in https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/28159#issuecomment-322184754
It allows to enable and disable repositories(also using wildcard * and ?) in a single task in order to perform the following tasks in a idempotent way(reporting a valid changed value in the result):
- Enable repositories foo and bar and disable all the other available repositories
- Enable all the available repositories excluding only foo and bar

It supports also the check mode

I tested the module on RHEL 6.7 ( subscription-manager-1.14.10-1.el6.x86_64 ) and RHEL 7.2 ( subscription-manager-1.15.9-15.el7.x86_64 ) with a rhsm account with about 500 repositories avaialable.
I tested the module also on RHEL 7.2 with subscription-manager register to Red Hat Satellite 6.2

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
redhat_repository

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
```
$ build/scripts-2.7/ansible --version
ansible 2.3.0.0
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
  python version = 2.7.13 (default, May 10 2017, 20:04:28) [GCC 6.3.1 20161221 (Red Hat 6.3.1-1)]

```


##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
I report below some examples and their output:

**List all repositories**
```
$ ./build/scripts-2.7/ansible -b gs-client01 -m redhat_repository -a list=enabled 
gs-client01 | SUCCESS => {
    "changed": false, 
    "failed": false, 
    "repositories": [
        {
            "enabled": true, 
            "id": "rhel-7-server-optional-rpms", 
            "name": "Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Server - Optional (RPMs)", 
            "url": "https://sat62.localdomain/pulp/repos/Org1/Library/RHEL7/content/dist/rhel/server/7/$releasever/$basearch/optional/os"
        }, 
        {
            "enabled": true, 
            "id": "rhel-7-server-satellite-tools-6.2-rpms",

            "url": "https://sat62.localdomain/pulp/repos/Org1/Library/RHEL7/content/dist/rhel/server/7/7Server/$basearch/sat-tools/6.2/os"
        }, 
        {
            "enabled": true,

        }

}

```


**Enable rhel-?-server-rpms and disable all the other repositories**
```
$ ./build/scripts-2.7/ansible -b gs-client01 -m redhat_repository -a "enable=rhel-?-server-rpms disable=*"
gs-client01 | SUCCESS => {
    "changed": false,

            {

As suggested in the previous comments, I have modified the list of parameter accepted by this modules using now a "Ansible style" parameters format.
I  report below some examples:
```
- name: List all RHSM repositories.
  redhat_repository:
    state: list

- name: List enabled RHSM repositories.
  redhat_repository:
    name: enabled
    state: list

- name: Enable a RHSM repository
  redhat_repository:
    name: rhel-7-server-rpms
    state: enabled

- name: Disable all RHSM repositories
  redhat_repository:
    name: '*'
    state: disabled

- name: Enable all repository starting with rhel-6-server
  redhat_repository:
    name: 'rhel-6-server*'
    state: enabled
```
Please could you react to my previous comment?

@jtyr : In the issue page there are already a couple of comment related to define a new ansible module for subscription-manager repository:
- [From @samdoran on June 13, 2016 19:55](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/28159#issuecomment-322184756) 
- [From @minusdavid on July 23, 2016 14:57](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/28159#issuecomment-322184773)

In my opinion, subscription-manager repositories and "traditional" yum repository managed by yum_repository have some differences and it could be difficult to manage both with yum_repository module only changing the yum_repository logic a bit to walk through all repo files for any of the actions.

A report below some differences between subscription-manager repositories and "traditional" yum repositories managed actually managed by yum_repository:
- In subscription-manager repositories options as baseurl,mirrorlist,description aren't required in yum_repository module and they aren't usually changed from default. In yum_repository this option are required https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/packaging/os/yum_repository.py#L708
- Enabling a repository using the command "subcription-manager repos --enable repo_name" execute some API calls to cdn.redhat.com, create/update ssl yum repo certificates in /etc/pki/entitlement/ . It doens't change only the parameter enabled in /etc/yum.repos.d/redhat.repo configuration file

I think the subscription-manager repository could be integrated in yum_repository module but another  options like a boolean named rhsm_repository should be addded to identify this type of repositories and manage them in a different way using "subscription-manager repos ..." commands but I think that the difficult of developing and testing this module will increase in order to manage two different type of objects.
Thanks for the explanation. If the `subcription-manager` actually does some calls back to CDN, then I think it's good to have an extra module for that.

```yaml
- name: List enabled RHSM repositories.
  redhat_repository:
    name: enabled
    state: list
```

It bugs me a little `name: enabled`
I think the following syntax is better

```yaml
- name: List enabled RHSM repositories.
  redhat_repository:
    state: list
    enabled: yes
```

So it will list enabled when `enabled: yes`  disabled when `enabled: no` and all when `enabled` is not defined. @sysadmind what do you think?

or even better

```yaml
- name: List enabled RHSM repositories.
  redhat_repository:
    list: enabled
```

Where list could be enabled|disabled|all
I'm not opposed to either way. If changing it, I like the `list` parameter idea better than the `enabled` parameter

Thanks for this review, with the last commit I have applied all the previous suggestions except:
- "In almost all modules the default is expected to be enabled." because in redhat_repository module the option list and state are mutually exclusive. If I assign a default value to list I can't enable repositories and viceversa
- https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/28292#discussion_r134698188 because I have replaced these error messages with built-in functions mutually_exclusive,required_one_of,required_if

@giovannisciortino I meant assigning the default value of `enabled` to the `state` option not the `list` option also `list` and `name` should be mutually exclusive not `list` and `state` Sorry for not stating it in a clearer way before.

Thank for the review.
I have fixed all the previous suggestions except https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/28292#discussion_r134861501 (if someone want to contribute to this  discussion with his opinion is welcome )

 and ask for comments on #ansible-devel

issues.title: [v2] 'Timeout (12s) waiting for privilege escalation prompt' when using with_items for commands that last longer than 12 seconds

labels.name: affects_2.0
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.0

labels.name: affects_2.1
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.1

labels.name: affects_2.2
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.2

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a bug.

labels.name: solaris
labels.description: Solaris community

issues.body:
**Issue Type**
Bug Report

**Component Name**
become

**Ansible version**

```
ansible 2.0.0 (stable-2.0 90021104d5) last updated 2015/11/24 08:59:25 (GMT +300)
  lib/ansible/modules/core: (detached HEAD 273112c56d) last updated 2015/11/24 09:00:04 (GMT +300)
  lib/ansible/modules/extras: (detached HEAD e46e2e1d6f) last updated 2015/11/24 09:00:04 (GMT +300)
```

(Any version starting with commit 9a8e95bff3d01cd06f193ead91997e21dc137bdb actually.)

**Summary**

When you have a task that uses `become` and `with_items`, and any of the items (except for the 1st one) takes longer than 12 seconds, Ansible v2 fails with

```
ERROR! Timeout (12s) waiting for privilege escalation prompt: BECOME-SUCCESS-nkcpdbuvzuejmtbyuzqwselaucozhqbs\r\n"
```

because it's waiting for the BECOME-SUCCESS-xxx marker assigned to loop item 1 while executing loop items 2 and further.

(When the command lasts shorter than the timeout, all you get is an unnecessary delay but no error.)

**Steps to Reproduce**

See [this comment](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/13278#issuecomment-159212874).

---

**Original description**

My usual "let's test my playbook on today's ansible 2.0 from git" failed with

```
TASK [fridge : git repo=git@fridge.pov.lt:/git/{{ item }}.git dest=/var/www/{{ item }}] ***
fatal: [precise]: FAILED! => {"failed": true, "msg": "ERROR! Timeout (12s) waiting for privilege escalation prompt: BECOME-SUCCESS-nkcpdbuvzuejmtbyuzqwselaucozhqbs\r\n"}
```

The task looks like this:

``` yaml
- git: repo=git@fridge.pov.lt:/git/{{ item }}.git dest=/var/www/{{ item }}
  with_items:
    - foo.pov.lt
    - bar.pov.lt
    - baz.pov.lt
  tags: websites
```

The output of `ansible -vvv` looks like this:

```
