comments_data.body:
Let's try to unpack the quoting:

```
/bin/sh -c 'sudo -H -S -n -u root /bin/sh -c '"'"'echo BECOME-SUCCESS-kgkgdyonvybkjovhnpcbhsocdkkukikb'"'"''
```

This is `/bin/sh` executing

```
sudo -H -S -n -u root /bin/sh -c 'echo BECOME-SUCCESS-kgkgdyonvybkjovhnpcbhsocdkkukikb'
```

which looks okay to me, but does not work for some reason -- it produces no output (and no error from sudo):

```
$ ssh -C -o ForwardAgent=yes -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o Port=2222 -o 'IdentityFile="/home/mg/src/deployments/provisioning/.vagrant/machines/precise/virtualbox/private_key"' -o KbdInteractiveAuthentication=no -o PreferredAuthentications=gssapi-with-mic,gssapi-keyex,hostbased,publickey -o PasswordAuthentication=no -o User=vagrant -o ConnectTimeout=10 -o ControlPath=/home/mg/.ansible/cp/ansible-ssh-%h-%p-%r -tt 127.0.0.1 sudo -H -S -n -u root sh -c 'echo BECOME-SUCCESS-kgkgdyonvybkjovhnpcbhsocdkkukikb'
Warning: Permanently added '[127.0.0.1]:2222' (ECDSA) to the list of known hosts.
```

Huh.  If I drop the `sh -c`, and quotes, then I get the desired output:

```
$ ssh -C -o ForwardAgent=yes -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o Port=2222 -o 'IdentityFile="/home/mg/src/deployments/provisioning/.vagrant/machines/precise/virtualbox/private_key"' -o KbdInteractiveAuthentication=no -o PreferredAuthentications=gssapi-with-mic,gssapi-keyex,hostbased,publickey -o PasswordAuthentication=no -o User=vagrant -o ConnectTimeout=10 -o ControlPath=/home/mg/.ansible/cp/ansible-ssh-%h-%p-%r -tt 127.0.0.1 sudo -H -S -n -u root echo BECOME-SUCCESS-kgkgdyonvybkjovhnpcbhsocdkkukikbWarning: Permanently added '[127.0.0.1]:2222' (ECDSA) to the list of known hosts.
BECOME-SUCCESS-kgkgdyonvybkjovhnpcbhsocdkkukikb
Connection to 127.0.0.1 closed.
```

I don't understand this.

Oh hey

```
$ ssh -C ... -tt 127.0.0.1 strace -f sh -c 'echo wat'
execve("/bin/sh", ["sh", "-c", "echo", "wat"], [/* 16 vars */]) = 0
...
```

And this is why it fails.

Adding one more level of quoting would make it work:

```
$ ssh -C ... -tt 127.0.0.1 "sh -c 'echo wat'"
wat
```

Never mind: `ansible-playbook -vvv` _lies to me_, and does not actually execute the commands it claims to be executing.

I tried to reproduce, and I see -vvv output containing

```
<localhost> SSH: EXEC ssh -C -q -o ControlMaster=auto -o ControlPersist=60s -o KbdInteractiveAuthentication=no -o PreferredAuthentications=gssapi-with-mic,gssapi-keyex,hostbased,publickey -o PasswordAuthentication=no -o ConnectTimeout=10 -o ControlPath=/home/mg/.ansible/cp/ansible-ssh-%h-%p-%r -tt localhost /bin/sh -c 'sudo -H -S -n -u mg /bin/sh -c '"'"'echo BECOME-SUCCESS-jidcfzolsnlaytjnjowgjiesjkijtqrh; LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=en_US.UTF-8 /usr/bin/python /tmp/ansible-tmp-1448352781.72-65353427623045/command'"'"''
```

which also doesn't work if I execute it from the shell, but Ansible actually succeeds, and strace confirms that the "/bin/sh -c '...'" bit is passed as a single argument:

```
execve("/usr/bin/ssh", ["/usr/bin/ssh", "-C", "-q", "-o", "ControlMaster=auto", "-o", "ControlPersist=60s", "-o", "KbdInteractiveAuthentication=no", "-o", "PreferredAuthentications=gssapi-with-mic,gssapi-keyex,hostbased,publickey", "-o", "PasswordAuthentication=no", "-o", "ConnectTimeout=10", "-o", "ControlPath=/home/mg/.ansible/cp/ansible-ssh-%h-%p-%r", "-tt", "localhost", "/bin/sh -c 'sudo -H -S -n -u mg /bin/sh -c '\"'\"'echo BECOME-SUCCESS-hxrdsqwlxhfaqeaaukwemxnyglaizznx; LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=en_US.UTF-8 /usr/bin/python /tmp/ansible-tmp-1448353157.19-275587866328999/command'\"'\"''"], [/* 73 vars */])
```

Yeah, it "lies to you", but when I was redoing that code I chose to leave that part alone. It's not feeding the entire command as a single string to a shell, after all, but using `execve` (indirectly, via `subprocess.Popen`). The choices are to leave it as-is, or introduce another level of `pipes.quote()` just for display to make the command fully cut-and-paste-able. Given that the quoting is already both pretty horrific and broken (e.g. #12290, #13179), I opted not to wrap it further.

But, given that `cmd` is sent as a single argument, I am puzzled by your sudo failure (it works for me at the moment with devel).

I checked with pstree -aup in the VM while ansible was running.

I see Ansible doing successful git clones for foo.pov.lt, bar.pov.lt, and then I see it doing

```
sshd,1166 -D
  ├─sshd,4422
  │   └─sshd,4524,vagrant 
  │       └─bash,4525
  │           └─pstree,7332 -aup 1166 -l
  └─sshd,6708
      └─sshd,6810,vagrant 
          └─sh,6988 -c sudo -H -S -n -u root /bin/sh -c 'echo BECOME-SUCCESS-twujfdrxzucbaagtolwawxsskbxgnrmt; LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=en_US.UTF-8 /usr/bin/python /home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/git; rm -rf "/home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/" > /dev/null 2>&1'
              └─sudo,6989,root -H -S -n -u root /bin/sh -c echo BECOME-SUCCESS-twujfdrxzucbaagtolwawxsskbxgnrmt; LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=en_US.UTF-8 /usr/bin/python /home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/git; rm -rf "/home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/" > /dev/null 2>&1
                  └─sh,6990 -c echo BECOME-SUCCESS-twujfdrxzucbaagtolwawxsskbxgnrmt; LANG=en_US.UTF-8 LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=en_US.UTF-8 /usr/bin/python /home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/git; rm -rf "/home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/" > /dev/null 2>&1
                      └─python,6991 /home/vagrant/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1448355742.59-61543405843328/git
                          └─git,7062 clone --origin origin git@fridge.pov.lt:/git/ivija.pov.lt.git /var/www/ivija.pov.lt
                              ├─git,7098 index-pack --stdin --fix-thin --keep=fetch-pack 7062 on vagrant-ubuntu-precise-64
                              ├─ssh,7063 git@fridge.pov.lt git-upload-pack '/git/ivija.pov.lt.git'
                              └─{git},7097
```

And then comes the timeout.

Conclusion: the `echo BECOME-SUCCESS ...` message is buffered somewhere so if the module takes a longer time to run, ansible times out prematurely.

Oh, my.  If I reorder the items in my task:

``` yaml
- git: repo=git@fridge.pov.lt:/git/{{ item }}.git dest=/var/www/{{ item }}
  with_items:
    - baz.pov.lt
    - foo.pov.lt
    - bar.pov.lt
  tags: websites
```

then Ansible v2 succeeds!

> Conclusion: the echo BECOME-SUCCESS ... message is buffered somewhere so if the module takes a longer time to run, ansible times out prematurely.

This is, um, **wrong**.

I looked at the source code:

```
                    raise AnsibleError('Timeout (%ds) waiting for privilege escalation prompt: %s' % (timeout, stdout))
```

`stdout` is the output received from the subprocess.

Somehow the state machine gets wedged and doesn't realize sudo was already successful.

I added some debugging prints and here's what's happening:

```
 --> state = 1
 --> stdout = 'BECOME-SUCCESS-iihpirenpoxwdzpoqpoktzmlirjtrozu\r\n'
 --> tmp_stdout = ''
 --> success_key = 'BECOME-SUCCESS-zcnvwvktilslzifcbygketvntxvhiqbt'
```

Debug code:

``` diff
diff --git a/lib/ansible/plugins/connection/ssh.py b/lib/ansible/plugins/connection/ssh.py
index 8bbc031..776aaa9 100644
--- a/lib/ansible/plugins/connection/ssh.py
+++ b/lib/ansible/plugins/connection/ssh.py
@@ -414,6 +414,15 @@ class Connection(ConnectionBase):

             if not rfd:
                 if state <= states.index('awaiting_escalation'):
+                    import sys
+                    sys.stderr.write('\n\n'
+                                     ' --> state = %r\n'
+                                     ' --> stdout = %r\n'
+                                     ' --> tmp_stdout = %r\n'
+                                     ' --> success_key = %r\n'
+                                     '\n'
+                                     % (state, stdout, tmp_stdout, self._play_context.success_key))
+                    sys.stderr.flush()
                     # If the process has already exited, then it's not really a
                     # timeout; we'll let the normal error handling deal with it.
                     if p.poll() is not None:
```
git bisect blames 9a8e95bff3d01cd06f193ead91997e21dc137bdb

**Steps to Reproduce**
- test.yml:

``` yaml
---
- hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: no
  tasks:
    - command: sleep {{item}}
      become: yes
      with_items:
        - 1
        - 15
```

**Expected Output**

```
$ ansible --version
ansible 1.9.4
  configured module search path = None
$ ansible-playbook -i localhost, test.yml 

PLAY [localhost] ************************************************************** 

TASK: [command sleep {{item}}] ************************************************ 
changed: [localhost] => (item=1)
changed: [localhost] => (item=15)

PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** 
localhost                  : ok=1    changed=1    unreachable=0    failed=0   
```

**Actual Output**

```
$ ansible --version
ansible 2.0.0 (stable-2.0 90021104d5) last updated 2015/11/24 08:59:25 (GMT +300)
  lib/ansible/modules/core: (detached HEAD 273112c56d) last updated 2015/11/24 09:00:04 (GMT +300)

PLAY RECAP *********************************************************************
localhost                  : ok=0    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1   
```
+1 can confirm this issue
@stephanadler if you set `_connected = False` on line 63 of `lib/ansible/plugins/connection/ssh.py`, does that fix it?
@amenonsen Yes, this fixes the issue.

Hello

this happens also on 2.0.0.2:

$ ansible --version
ansible 2.0.0.2
  config file = /Users/misko/.ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides

`TASK [copy ssh key(s)] *********************************************************
fatal: [myhostname.local]: FAILED! => {"failed": true, "msg": "ERROR! Timeout (12s) waiting for privilege escalation prompt: "}`
Just happening with 2.0.0.2

is [this fix](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/92ea5c9f7bcd1c2f9cbd9d821d83434de0c48c1a) planned for 2.0.1 or is there going to be an earlier patch to 2.0.0.x?

running 2.0.0.2 and experiencing the issue as well.

thx for the fix btw :cake:
This is affecting us as well and causing some major headaches.

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY

Updates module to use boto3. Adds parameters:

instance_id
placement_tenancy

Also added a second example using instance_id and updated the docs with the new parameters.

##### ISSUE TYPE

Sorry for adding the conflict (merged another rename PR). When you rebase, could you insert the entries for your module before the new entries? I'll soon create another PR and will add entries for that one after them, then our PRs won't conflict :)

> Sorry for adding the conflict (merged another rename PR). When you rebase, could you insert the entries for your module before the new entries? I'll soon create another PR and will add entries for that one after them, then our PRs won't conflict :)

Sure, working on it

@felixfontein @pratikgadiya12 Thanks for taking so much efforts for this PR. We are currently refactoring VMware testcases in major way, so I would like to hold the PR for a while. Once we have that PR in place I will merge this. Thanks for the patients.
@Akasurde I hope this won't introduce a lot of conflicts with this PR, since it also has to change several of the tests.

> > Looks good, except the renamed module return values.
> 
> @felixfontein that will break backwards compatibility.

Exactly, that's why this no longer happens in this PR.

> should we return both for now? something like:
> 
> ```
> module.exit_json(changed=False,
>     hosts_vmnics_facts = host_vmnic_mgr.gather_host_vmnic_info(), 
>     hosts_vmnics_info = host_vmnic_mgr.gather_host_vmnic_info())
> ```

I would stick to the old name, until there is a good mechanism to deprecate / rename return values. Currently there isn't.
@Akasurde @goneri what's the current state with the tests refactoring?

Thanks @pratikgadiya12 for your patch. It currently conflicts with the `devel` branch. I suggest you to break up this change in a series of smaller commits and open on PR per patch. This way the review will be easier and you will reduce the exposure to potential merge conflict.

> @Akasurde @goneri what's the current state with the tests refactoring?

The test refactoring is mostly done. Since the CI uses a HTTP proxy to access the test lab, we need to land: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/52936 and https://github.com/vmware/pyvmomi/pull/799

> > @Akasurde @goneri what's the current state with the tests refactoring?
> 
> The test refactoring is mostly done. Since the CI uses a HTTP proxy to access the test lab, we need to land: #52936 and [vmware/pyvmomi#799](https://github.com/vmware/pyvmomi/pull/799)

@goneri Sure. I will wait for both the patches to merge and then will start working on this.
vmware/pyvmomi#799 is merged, #52936 is still to go.
BTW, Ansible's feature freeze is in one month. So we really shouldn't delay this much longer.
The refactoring patches are merged and I'm waiting for a release of pyvmomi with the fix. This being said I agree with @felixfontein. I don't mind doing manual run of the functional tests for now.
@pratikgadiya12 I think that means you can rebase / fix this PR, if you have time :) If not, tell me, then I can try to rebase this PR (assuming you ticked that magic checkbox).

> @pratikgadiya12 I think that means you can rebase / fix this PR, if you have time :) If not, tell me, then I can try to rebase this PR (assuming you ticked that magic checkbox).

Sure, will resume working on this from tomorrow.
@pratikgadiya12 any news?
@felixfontein @pratikgadiya12 VMware test infra is not stable, yet. I would suggest to wait for @goneri @jillr heads up before proceeding with this PR. Thanks.

@Akasurde the main problem is that feature freeze for Ansible 2.9 is coming up soon (less than three weeks!). We already delayed renaming the modules for two months, waiting for the test refactoring to complete. Updating this PR and getting it merged also takes some amount of time, and I really don't want to delay that until the last minute. When will the test refactoring be done so we can proceed with this?

shipit
Could you please add "check_mode" tests?

Check mode tests usually work as follows. Every test consists of four steps:
 1) do change in check mode
 2) do change for real
 3) do change again in check mode
 4) do change again for real

(3 and 4 can be swapped)

The idea is that both 1 and 2 should result in changes, and 3 and 4 not (idempotency).

@nitzmahone 

> Checking code coverage, looks like we should have the other supported key types represented in tests, ...

I added integration tests for all supported keys.

> ... and maybe some unit tests or something that exercises the NotImplemented and runtime-checkable protocol fallback code.

I thought about tests for the `NotImplementedError` cases and concluded that it would either be just unit tests that use the methods incorrectly or constructing a fake ssh agent that sends invalid responses and I don't think either case is really practical. @nitzmahone  HI Matt, ux is refined.  To create a windows web app, you could specify python_version, php_version multiple framework version at same time, except for java_version, which is mutually exclusive with others. To create a linux web app, you could specify only one framework version, like node 6.6, or java 1.8. Since windows and linux webapp creation behaves differently, now the module have 2 top level arguments:
- windows_framework, which is a list of suboptions of supported framework.
- linux_framework, which let user specify name and version.

pls review. thanks.

issues.body:
SUMMARY

Add additional mapping attributes for VM/Template registration

ISSUE TYPE

Feature Pull Request
COMPONENT NAME

lib/ansible/modules/cloud/ovirt/ovirt_templates.py
lib/ansible/modules/cloud/ovirt/ovirt_vms.py

ANSIBLE VERSION

ansible 2.4.0
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Add additional mappings params for entity registration

As part of the effort to support DR with oVirt
the "Register" operation is being added with a new mapping parameter
that describes the configuration of the registration.

The idea of supporting DR site to site in oVirt is to have 2 active
setups using storage replication between the primary setup and the
secondary setup.
Both setups will have active DCs, clusters, and hosts, although those
will not be identical.
The user can define a mapping which will be used to recover its setup.

Each mapping can be used to map any entity's attribute stored in the OVF
with its correlated entity.
For example, there could be a primary setup with an entity configured on cluster A.
We also keep an active secondary setup which only have cluster B.
Cluster B is compatible for that entity and in case of a DR scenario theoretically
the storage domain can be imported to the secondary setup and the use can
register the entity to cluster B.

In that case, we can automate the recovery process by defining a cluster mapping,
so once the entity will be registered its OVF will indicate it belongs to
cluster A but the mapping which will be sent will indicate that cluster B should
be valid for every thing that is configured on cluster A.
The engine should do the switch, and register the entity to cluster B in the
secondary site.

Cluster mapping is just one example.
The following list describes the different mappings which were
introduced:
LUN mapping
Role mapping
Permissions mapping
Affinity group mapping
Affinity label mapping

Each mapping will be used for its specific OVF's data once the register operation
will take place in the engine.

If you think it will be more nice to do that with prefix please let me know and I will change it
Will change the rest of the mappings to specifically indicate name

issues.title: New module: Add amazon cloudfront distribution module. (cloud/amazon/cloudfront_distribution)

labels.name: needs_revision
labels.description: This PR fails CI tests or a maintainer has requested a review/revision of the PR.

labels.name: new_plugin
labels.description: This PR includes a new plugin.

labels.name: new_module
labels.description: This PR includes a new module.

labels.description: This issue/PR relates to a module.

labels.name: ci_verified
labels.description: Changes made in this PR are causing tests to fail.

labels.name: affects_2.4
labels.description: This issue/PR affects Ansible v2.4

labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible community.

labels.name: support:core
labels.description: This issue/PR relates to code supported by the Ansible Engineering Team.

issues.body:
#### SUMMARY

This module allows the following cloudfront actions:

- create distribution
- update distribution
- delete distribution
- create streaming distribution
- update streaming distribution
- delete streaming distribution
- tag a resource
- untag a resource
- generate a pre-signed cloudfront url from a PEM private key

I saw this as a gap item as the `cloudfront_facts.py` module already exists but not `cloudfront.py`.

Each action has a set of valid parameters that an be used in conjunction. These are illustrated in the examples section.

This PR also renames the class for `cloudfront_facts.py` as `CloudfrontFactsManager` as `CloudfrontManager` is more appropriate for this module.

#### ISSUE TYPE

New Module Pull Request

#### COMPONENT NAME

./lib/ansible/modules/cloud/amazon/cloudfront.py

#### ANSIBLE VERSION

```
ansible 2.3.0 (devel 652b4d220a) last updated 2017/04/30 23:12:22 (GMT +1100)
  config file =
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
  python version = 2.7.10 (default, Feb  6 2017, 23:53:20) [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 8.0.0 (clang-800.0.34)]
```

#### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

This PR is migrated from PR #24151 as the branch and PR comment history was irreparable and has thus been closed.

comments from @willthames:

`create_streaming_distribution` and `delete_streaming_distribution` and the other similarly named parameters are of concern - we should be stating the desired state of `streaming_distribution` (present or absent).

This feels like it should probably be multiple modules.

The use of `tag_resource` and `untag_resource` is problematic - just provide a `tags:` parameter and update tags accordingly

comments from @wilvk:

Thanks for the feedback @willthames ! I'll get onto those changes:

consolidate tag and untag into just `tags:`
use `status` parameter instead of `create_distribution` `delete_distribution` `update_distribution` `duplicate_distribution` `validate_distribution` etc.
could possibly be multiple modules but not sure how it should be split - distribution and streaming_distribution have dependencies/common methods. Am open to suggestions, however..

I don't see how this module can be idempotent as there's no state parameter. It's more procedural which is not really the ansible way. 

You should have a purge_tags option if you're supporting tags to decide what to do with existing tags that aren't defined in the playbook.

@wilvk this PR contains the following merge comits:

* https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/36b2a4810258c60a3588cc5767e51ae42a7efec1

Please [rebase your branch](http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/dev_guide/developing_rebasing.html) to remove these commits.

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: merge_commit_notify --->

@willthames @wimnat ready_for_review !

Changes include:
- changed `tag_resource` and `untag_resource` to just `tags` and a `purge_tags` parameters.
- changed all create update delete duplicate verify action parameters to just 2 parameters:
    - resource
    - state
where `resource` is one of `distribution`, `streaming_distribution`, `invalidation` and `origin_access_identity`
and `state` is one of `present`, `absent`, `updated`, `duplicated` and `verified`
- added more thorough documentation.
- various minor fixes

As is the `updated` state is not very reliable due to inconsistencies in required parameters between the boto3 `create_distribution` and `update_distribution` calls.  I've documented the problem at https://github.com/boto/boto3/issues/1083 upstream.

When trying to use `updated` to manage a distribution without specifying all parameters (even non-required ones) errors like this bubble up:

```
TASK [create cloudfront distribution] *******************************************************
An exception occurred during task execution. To see the full traceback, use -vvv. The error w
as: IllegalUpdate: An error occurred (IllegalUpdate) when calling the UpdateDistribution oper
ation: OriginReadTimeout is required for updates.
```

If this is in fact an upstream AWS requirement in the `UpdateDistribution` API this module will need to enforce adding those parameters.  That would either require:

1) Extending the default value management in this module to non-required parameters.
2) Merging the current configuration with the module parameters.  This would be ideal but is not trivial to implement.

@wilvk any thoughts about how to proceed here?

@wilvk I also have a small fix for missing `quantity` fields at https://github.com/meredith-digops/ansible/commit/7898b4724a89e15706072183bad47d88b101556b.  I can't seem to open a PR against your fork.  Can you take a look and lift that patch if it makes sense to you?

Thanks for the feedback @shawnsi ! I've implemented your two suggestions:
- add quantity to `allowed_methods` and `cached_methods` - done slightly different as there is already a method to do the quantity for an aws list
- set `default_trusted_signers` to false - for consistency and logic

WRT `OriginReadTimeOut` - I didn't notice that attribute as an issue specifically, but I did notice the inconsistencies you mention with update vs create and have catered for them where I encountered them. I think there was only one instance where I had to make concessions to 'back-fill' with defaults for this circumstance.
@wilvk do you have examples of accommodating the additional required values for the `update_distribution` calls?

@shawnsi unfortunately not - from memory it was a minor fix, like an attribute name had to be present even though there was nothing in it - so I just set to `foo = ''` or `foo = {}`. I vaguely remember there was an SO question highlighting the same issue.

@ryansb I've made a few more changes if that's ok, including:
- added method for getting `(streaming_)distribution_id` from `caller_reference` as this is also a valid identifier and can determine whether the distribution is created or updated (if included).
- fixed/cleaned up documentation
- added defaults for custom origin `ReadTimeout` and `KeepaliveTimeout`as these values are required for updates but not create calls (as mentioned earlier by @shawnsi).
- more formatting for pep8

The test `ansible-test sanity --test pep8` failed with the following error:
```
lib/ansible/modules/cloud/amazon/cloudfront_distribution.py:1715:55: E128 continuation line under-indented for visual indent
```
<!-- job_id: 592c1359c939870700dbb304 -->

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: shippable_test_result --->

Hi @ryansb I think what is happening when that playbook is run twice is that it is actually creating two cloudfront distributions. As the `default_domain_name_origin` is not a unique identifier, it is not found in the list of distributions and thus creates a new distribution each time. The `default_domain_name_origin` is what the distribution looks at to get the data for the distribution and can be identical over multiple distributions. Each alias in `aliases[]`, however, cannot be identical and must be unique over multiple distributions as it is what is used by the end-user to access the distribution (if a cloudfront.net domain name is not used). 

As the `caller_reference` value is not set, there is nothing to identify the distribution as unique from the playbook. If the `caller_reference` is not set, it is generated internally in the module as a datetime stamp, (for example: "caller_reference": "2017-05-31T22:05:49.067767"). Using the following playbook with a `caller_reference` set still produces `changed=true`.

```
---
- hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: no
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - cloudfront_distribution:
        state: present
        default_origin_domain_name: anywhere.com
        caller_reference: unique distribution
        comment: modified by ansible cloudfront.py
```

Looking into this and running the playbook with `-vvv` I can see that the `e_tag` and the `last_modified_time` fields have actually changed even though nothing in the distribution has changed. This must be expected behaviour by AWS when a request to update a distribution has been made from the API. I could do a comparison of the distribution config before and after the API call and if there are no changes to set `changed=false`, but even this may be incorrect as at a minimum, the last modified time and `e_tag` values have changed. Alternatively, I could compare the current distribution config to the proposed changes and if identical, skip the update and set `changed=false`, but this may be a bit excessive and complicated to implement. Let me know what you think.


Testing this I identified a bug where it was checking aliases as distribution_ids and have fixed accordingly.

I adapted from the one embedded i use in [this role i made](https://github.com/archf/ansible-sql-runner). If anyone shows interests i can also make a PR for the impala_query module.

Another issue, this stanza from over in my original PR #20793 is more or less necessary to handle any schema with timestamps in it:
```python
    # Setup a datetime to string case
    def cast_timestamp(value, cur):
        if value is None:
            return None
        return str(value)

    cursor.execute("SELECT NULL::timestamp")
    oid = cursor.description[0][1]
    sqltype = psycopg2.extensions.new_type((oid,), "timestamp", cast_timestamp)
    psycopg2.extensions.register_type(sqltype)
```
There are probably some more that should be handled, but this one handles an obvious case and presumably we just extend it if we find more canonical uses cases.

Thanks for your review. Regarding the autocommit I think however having versionned and self-contained `.sql` scripts is valuable. A developer might develop scripts outside of `ansible` before passing them to ops or devops guys for deployment with ansible. It also allows to deploy entire apps from simple scripts sorted in alphabetical order on filesystem.

 For sure using `postgresql_db` is the ansible way to do it. `postgresql_db` enables autocommit. I don't remember how they handles check_mode. They may have the same shortcomings.

Autocommit is not the default and for sure subsequent tasks in `check_mode` would fail if skipping those. It is an advanced feature for those knowing what they are doing. Tasks using autocommit should be explicitly isolated if they need to be skipped to avoid reporting "changed task"  and that could be achieve with tags or in different play or whatever the mean.

For the timestamps, what's the default behavior? Value is interpreted as an integer instead of string?

This happens when you pass a non-standard structure back to the ansible module - the issue is the Psycopg2 dictionary iterator. You need to iterate it and yield the actual dictionaries.

@pilou- this module lets you send parameterized queries to Postgres, and retrieve the data as JSON dictionaries, which makes for easy and consistent access as registered variables or facts within an ansible playbook.

It also fills an obvious gap in the module space - utilities to create databases and users are somewhat pointless without the ability to initialize them, and for applications which use Postgres as a backend you generally want idempotent setup to happen - e.g. the original version of this I wrote to handle configuring auth providers in Gogs while provisioning Postgres databases and users for Gogs.

It's about tighter integration with ansible. Passing values, returning
values...

Else in the spirit of what you said there would be only 3 modules in
ansible: raw, shell and command.

> +            "UPSERT" in statusmessage or "DELETE" in statusmessage):
> +        changed = True
> +
> +    if changed:
> +        if module.check_mode:
> +            db_connection.rollback()
> +        else:
> +            db_connection.commit()
> +
> +    db_connection.close()
>
> db_connection.close() is not called when cursor.execute raises an
> exception.
> ------------------------------
>
> In lib/ansible/modules/database/postgresql/postgresql_query.py
> <https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/25411#discussion_r128402533>:
>
> > +    # prepare args
> +    if module.params["positional_args"] is not None:
> +        arguments = module.params["positional_args"]
> +
> +    elif module.params["named_args"] is not None:
> +        arguments = module.params["named_args"]
> +
> +    try:
> +        cursor.execute(query, arguments)
> +    except Exception:
> +        e = get_exception()
> +        module.fail_json(msg="Unable to execute query: %s" % e,
> +                         query_arguments=arguments)
> +
> +    ansible_facts = {}
> +    query_results = []
>
> rowcount could be set to 0 then the else block of the conditional
> statement could be removed.
> ------------------------------
>
> In lib/ansible/modules/database/postgresql/postgresql_query.py
> <https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/25411#discussion_r128405135>:
>
> > +
> +        rowcount = len(query_results)
> +        fact = module.params["fact"]
> +        if fact is not None:
> +            ansible_facts = {fact: query_results}
> +    else:
> +        rowcount = 0
> +
> +    statusmessage = cursor.statusmessage
> +
> +    changed = False
> +
> +    # set changed flag only on non read-only command
> +    if ("UPDATE" in statusmessage or "INSERT" in statusmessage or
> +            "UPSERT" in statusmessage or "DELETE" in statusmessage):
> +        changed = True
>
> What about MOVE, COPY, CREATE ? It doesn't seem reliable, changed should
> be True if the query has been executed. By the way I am not sure if
> supporting check_mode is a good idea. command and shell modules don't
> support check_mode, it would be fine it this module didn't support
> check_mode.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/25411#pullrequestreview-51072727>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGSSfJyXsJaeYnrhYVuX6cTQXpdscqrcks5sPqlTgaJpZM4NyGka>
> .
>
@archf just for you to know, Ansible 2.4 feature freeze for community module is planned for 29 August 2017.

@archf I think based on @pilou- comments that the check_mode should be removed for the time being. Without a truly comprehensive test suite I feel like the risk of it doing something it shouldn't is just too high (and ergo, is making getting this merged trickier).

The test `ansible-test sanity --test boilerplate` failed with the following error:
```
Command "test/sanity/code-smell/boilerplate.sh" returned exit status 2.
>>> Standard Output
== Missing __metaclass__ = type ==
./lib/ansible/modules/database/postgresql/postgresql_query.py

== Missing from __future__ import (absolute_import, division, print_function) ==
./lib/ansible/modules/database/postgresql/postgresql_query.py
```

Thanks a lot @pilou- and @wrouesnel for you review. I made a first patch from your comments. I'll try to cover remaining stuff before the weekend (module args & documentation fragments)...

Some more update. Maybe as @pilou- suggested we should have a separate arg for script file. I'd like the thing to look in the role `files` or `scripts` directory. Not sure how to do that thought.

I feel like the other things such as the args and some exceptions should be solved in all postgresql modules at the same time by improving pgutils as bit. I'll need to sleep on this...

Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

- Sanity tests: work with both podman and docker for me
- Unit tests: work with both podman and docker for me
- Integration tests, default container: work with both podman and docker for me
- Integration tests, ubuntu2204 container: work with both podman and docker for me
- Integration tests, centos7 container: **does not work with podman and docker**: `Container centos7 requires cgroup v1, but the container host only provides cgroup v2.`; with the instructions provided, runs fine with docker, but **not with podman** (SSH daemon - does not seem to start)
- Integration tests, fedora36 container: work with both podman and docker for me
- Integration tests, alpine3 container: work with both podman and docker for me

BTW: the cgroups instructions recommend to run `chown -R {user}.{group} /sys/fs/cgroup/systemd`; shouldn't it be `chown -R {user}:{group} /sys/fs/cgroup/systemd`, with `:` instead of `.` between user and group?

@felixfontein Thanks for testing. I'll fix the chown instructions. Can you provide the diagnostic output from the centos7 failure with podman? You should see output like this:

```

...
Checking container systemd logs...
...
Checking SSH debug output...
...
```

> BTW: the cgroups instructions recommend to run `chown -R {user}.{group} /sys/fs/cgroup/systemd`; shouldn't it be `chown -R {user}:{group} /sys/fs/cgroup/systemd`, with `:` instead of `.` between user and group?

I thought the same thing, but the command did not show any error, and the ownership was correct after I ran it. However, I did not check to see if the ownership was already correct before running it, but I doubt it since I used `sudo` and since the `mkdir` command did not have `-p` then it should have failed if the directory already existed.

lib/ansible/modules/package_facts.py:0:0: doc-choices-do-not-match-spec: Argument 'manager' in argument_spec defines choices as ([['apt'], ['auto'], ['pacman'], ['pkg'], ['portage'], ['rpm']]) but documentation defines choices as ([['auto'], ['rpm'], ['apt'], ['portage'], ['pkg'], ['pacman'], ['apk']])
```

@aminvakil the error comes because in `devel` branch, `apk` was added to the list in DOCUMENTATION (https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/package_facts.py#L24). Since shippable automatically rebases against `devel`, and you didn't touch that list, the resulting file processed by ansible-test has a longer list in DOCUMENTATION (the one from `devel`) than in the argument spec (the list you added).
(And because you didn't touch the documentation list, there's no conflict.)

> @aminvakil the error comes because in `devel` branch, `apk` was added to the list in DOCUMENTATION (https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/package_facts.py#L24). Since shippable automatically rebases against `devel`, and you didn't touch that list, the resulting file processed by ansible-test has a longer list in DOCUMENTATION (the one from `devel`) than in the argument spec (the list you added).

issues.body:
SUMMARY

This module (icinga2_host) allows the use of the Icinga2 REST API (https://www.icinga.com/docs/icinga2/latest/doc/12-icinga2-api/) to manage a host definition in Icinga2.

ISSUE TYPE

    New Module Pull Request

COMPONENT NAME

    icinga2_host

ANSIBLE VERSION

    2.5.0

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

modules to follow are
 - icinga2_service (manage services to monitor)
 - icinga2_downtime (manage downtime for hosts)

All 3 modules together will make it possible for a playbook to make sure the host(s) are monitored, they are down while running the playbook (no alarms are send) and manage the services that need to be monitored.

Please let me know if I can improve / help this along in any way.

@nitzmahone the function map code has issues, specially when you see how some collections have their plugins and being AST is extreeeemly slow, this is what i normally get stuck at, so i removed that option from this first push

also tests and filters don't really need config, just documentation since they take their arguments directly, lookups are the only real hybrid case.

```

issues.body:
##### SUMMARY
<!--- Describe the change below, including rationale and design decisions -->
This idea behind this module was to have something that could help us set "FS-Data-Deduplication" settings on a Windows volume.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/deduplication/

We have that feature enabled in my company and we use to lower disk usage on specific disks.
We thought it could be an nice addition for the Ansible community.
<!--- HINT: Include "Fixes #nnn" if you are fixing an existing issue -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest -->
- New Module Pull Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Write the short name of the module, plugin, task or feature below -->
win_data_deduplication
##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!--- Include additional information to help people understand the change here -->
As far as my tests go, this is idempotent.
`WhatIf` is not supported by the Powershell commands used in this module so I couldn't add a check_mode support.
I've created tests based on the `win_format` module tests.
<!--- Paste verbatim command output below, e.g. before and after your change -->
Usage:
```
win_data_deduplication:
    drive_letter: "D"
    state: present
    settings:
      no_compress: true
      minimum_file_age_days: 1
      minimum_file_size: 0
```

Result:
```paste below
TASK [windows : win_data_deduplication | Enable Data Deduplication on D:] **********************************************************************************************************************************************************************
Monday 29 July 2019  14:22:13 +0200 (0:00:00.132)       0:00:11.371 ***********
Monday 29 July 2019  14:22:13 +0200 (0:00:00.132)       0:00:11.369 ***********
changed: [REDACTED] => (item=D)
changed: [REDACTED] => (item=D)
ok: [REDACTED] => (item=D)
changed: [REDACTED] => (item=D)
```

Not sure why I have fails on the additional disk not being available.
I'll investigate later.

From the test, it looks like there is some kind of race condition that prevents the vhdx file from being accessed. Maybe it is solely caused by "The specified drive letter is not free to be assigned." have you tried to use a different drive letter, or mounting to a directory like C:/mount?

And from the other test, this https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/59723/files#diff-cbffd3f097e8a03d3ce35965768cb030R159 should most likely be a try catch, as the exception `No MSFT_Volume objects found with property 'DriveLetter' equal to 'T'.` is failing your code instead of skipping the if statement (what I think you're trying to do there).

This looks like a nice feature to have.
Consider adding a check to make sure the version of windows supports Storage Spaces which I think was added in Server 2012.  There's an example of checking the os version in win_domain.ps1 L39-41 (although there it is checking for Server 2012 R2 or later).
I had to rebase from devel because of a conflict issue.

I have yet to understand how to have a proper NTFS volume to make the tests work.
I have tested this module with Azure Windows VMs and it works as expected. So I'll definitely need some help I think.

ready_for_review

FYI, I've implemented most of the changes asked for.
One thing that I haven't touched are the Exceptions catching, I'll need to dedicate more time on that (personal time).

Latest build is marked as unstable because there was a retry on the Windows 2012R2 test.
Windows 2016 and 2019 didn't flinch.
I've also tested in an environment with molecule and it consistently worked.

There's definitely something weird with the fact that I need an additional disk to test this feature. Again, I don't have enough knowledge on the build pipeline to really assert why it would be failing sometimes.
Is there anyway to trigger a build with no code change?
@rnsc - you can close and open your PR and that will trigger another CI build.

I fixed the tests

ready_for_review

> Just did a first pass on the module and have added my comments. I think you should revisit the UI for the settings interface into something that is less of a wrapper around the cmdlet. You should be implementing each set parameter as an actual module option in a snake_case format to keep to the standard Ansible follows. It may be more work to add each option but you get a better experience for user's actually going in now they can see what is supported and how rather than forcing them to go to an external doc and then trying to understand that.

@jborean93 Thank you for the review, I'll work on enhancing this PR based on your comments soon :)

@gustavomcarmo could you add an integration test before we can merge?

@zikalino This is the content of the playbook used for integration tests (inventory.yml):

```yml
---
- hosts: localhost
  connection: local
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
  - name: Get the resource group VMs facts
    azure_rm_virtualmachine_facts:
      resource_group: Dev_Devops1
    register: facts_result
  - name: Generate the inventory file
    lineinfile:
      path: ./hosts
      create: yes
      line: '{{item.name}} ansible_ssh_host={{item.properties.networkProfile.networkInterfaces[0].properties.ipConfigurations[0].properties.publicIPAddress.properties.ipAddress}}'
      state: present
    with_items: '{{facts_result.ansible_facts.azure_virtualmachines}}'
```

And this is the content of the generated inventory file (hosts):

```txt
confluence ansible_ssh_host=191.232.165.120
jenkins ansible_ssh_host=191.232.188.160
osazure ansible_ssh_host=191.235.85.42
osdev ansible_ssh_host=104.41.49.84
```

@zikalino When the virtual machines are filtered by tag:

```yml
---
- hosts: localhost
  connection: local
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
  - name: Get the resource group VMs facts
    azure_rm_virtualmachine_facts:
      resource_group: Dev_Devops1
      tags:
        - displayName:jenkins
    register: facts_result
  - name: Generate the inventory file
    lineinfile:
      path: ./hosts
      create: yes
      line: '{{item.name}} ansible_ssh_host={{item.properties.networkProfile.networkInterfaces[0].properties.ipConfigurations[0].properties.publicIPAddress.properties.ipAddress}}'
      state: present
    with_items: '{{facts_result.ansible_facts.azure_virtualmachines}}'
```
The hosts file is generated with a single line, corresponding to the single VM with such tag:
```txt
jenkins ansible_ssh_host=191.232.188.160
```

And when the name of the virtual machine is specified:
```yml
---
- hosts: localhost
  connection: local
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
  - name: Get the resource group VMs facts
    azure_rm_virtualmachine_facts:
      resource_group: Dev_Devops1
      name: confluence
    register: facts_result
  - name: Generate the inventory file
    lineinfile:
      path: ./hosts
      create: yes
      line: '{{item.name}} ansible_ssh_host={{item.properties.networkProfile.networkInterfaces[0].properties.ipConfigurations[0].properties.publicIPAddress.properties.ipAddress}}'
      state: present
    with_items: '{{facts_result.ansible_facts.azure_virtualmachines}}'
```

commit.message:
Add AnsiballZ debugging support with debugpy (#85476)

* Add AnsiballZ debugging support with debugpy

Adds support for debugging AnsiballZ modules with debugpy which is used
by VSCode as its Python debugger DAP. Debugging can either be done
through a manual Debugpy listening server through a launch.json
configuration or through the new ansible-test --dev-debug-on-deman
argument.

* Fix up integration test

* Simplify config option and move mypy ignore

* Use new API if available and fix typo

* Guard the import of debugpy

* Fix sanity import issue

* Minor cosmetic adjustments

* Simplify debugger setup

* ansible-test - Refactor debugging interface

* Add ansible-test debug integration tests

* Fix ansible-test shell when in unsupported dir

---------

commit.message:
Short-circuit legacy network module prefix->action mapping (#85406)

* Short-circuit legacy network module prefix->action mapping

* Modified a non-short-circuit compound conditional in a legacy networking path that attempted to resolve an action for any module name containing `_`. The bug was always present, but the typical presentation (an ImportError) was ignored prior to 2.19.
* The legacy networking path should be deprecated and removed in 2.20- a module could still be run under the wrong action if one with a matching prefix is found.

* unit test fix

commit.message:
Limit askpass prompts to single attempt (#85364)

* Limit askpass prompts to single attempt

OpenSSH client option NumberOfPasswordPrompts defaults to 3 so in case
an incorrect connection password is provided it is excessively tried 3
times. Not only that but running the `_ssh_askpass` entry point multiple
times (via ssh) results in `json.decoder.JSONDecodeError` as after the
first run the shared memory is zero'd and the subsequent runs end up
calling `json.loads` on empty data.

`json.decoder.JSONDecodeError` does not happen prior to Python 3.13 as
the share memory is unlinked automatically on `.close()` and the
`_ssh_askpass` entry point exits with return code 1 before attempting to
load zero'd memory.

Fixes #85359

* changelog and tests

* Update changelogs/fragments/85359-askpass-incorrect-password-retries.yml

Co-authored-by: Matt Davis <6775756+nitzmahone@users.noreply.github.com>

* Update lib/ansible/cli/_ssh_askpass.py

Co-authored-by: Martin Krizek <martin.krizek@gmail.com>

* Avoid race condition in second unlink

---------

Co-authored-by: Matt Davis <6775756+nitzmahone@users.noreply.github.com>
Co-authored-by: Matt Clay <matt@mystile.com>

verification.payload:
tree 13e98b7de52db56b81c87f3c8ef3acd93a708772
parent fcffd707c6f8d959d7dc7c6e7a91fa2f59fd0308
author Martin Krizek <martin.krizek@gmail.com> 1751076093 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1751076093 +0000

commit.message:
Remove redundant vars FA on PlaybookInclude (#85395)

commit.message:
unified Marker propagation for all Jinja plugin/call ops (#85391)

* Errors raised in most Jinja operations and plugin invocations are now propagated as Markers, allowing template pipeline to continue execution when a Marker-aware consumer is present.
* Added ability to inspect ExceptionMarkers to Protomatter `dump_object` filter.
* Added tests.

Co-authored-by: Matt Clay <matt@mystile.com>
